The interior holds an unbeatable Gothic carving of the Virgin dating back to the 16th century. Likewise, there was an older carving (15th century) of María Magdalena that was transferred to Donostia-San Sebastián, later on.

galeria.titulo: The hermitage of Nuestra Señora de la Antigua
The hermitage of Nuestra Señora de la Antigua
The hermitage of Nuestra Señora de la Antigua

datosGenerales.descripcion: Hermitage dedicated to San Lorenzo in the past is nowadays located on the outskirts of the centre of town, in Galartza neighbourhood and surrounded by beautiful views. Now its patron saint is Santa Agueda, whose celebration is held on February 5th with the blessing of bread and seeds. Mass service is celebrated on that day. The one-nave hermitage has been restored on many occasions. There, several events took place. In 1984, for instance, a 13th century carving of the Virgin Mary was stolen from the major altarpiece. Fortunately, it was recovered later.

The outstanding Muntsaratz tower is one of the best known lineage's house of the Duranguesado region. The original building dated back to the 9th century but the Muntsaratz lineage decided to restore the building and turn it into a magnificent Renaissance tower.

 

In the beginning it was a fortified tower. Proof of it is the ground floor, which is quite hermetic. It only consists of little openings for horses and the building entrance. Above it the visitor can gaze at the lineage's coat of arms. The Muntsaratz family made a palace of the house, and the upper floors bear testimony to that fact. The second floor is quite open and either of two main façades present arches that make the building more beautiful.

 

The upper floor is a humble wood and brick structure. The building is crowned with a large roof. Nowadays it is the headquarters of the Fundación Kalitatea Foundation.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Santa María de la Asunción
datosGenerales.descripcion: Church of Santa María de la Asunción's construction works began in the second half of the 16th century. It is a one-nave Renaissance church whose nave is divided into five equal stretches, the second one has two chapels that confer cross shape to the church. The apse is octagonal and the choir is located at the other side. Outside, walls are built in ordinary masonry and the tower, with its majestic belfry, stands out. The temple consists of three entrances, the main one is a two-storey triumphal arch with a majestic façade door-altarpiece. In the interior it is worth mentioning the high altarpiece, built in wood following Rococo style.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Chorale concerts.

galeria.titulo: Church of Santa María de la Asunción

datosGenerales.descripcion: The Asunción de Nuestra Señora church is a magnificent, gothic 14th-century building. It was erected with four chapels in the main part and three chapels in the presbytery. It also has a polygonal gothic apse and special vaults. If the temple is overall one of the best examples of the gothic style in the Basque Country, its Western front is one of the jewells of the Renaissance art of the 16th century, like the choir. Finally, there are interesting graves with lying sculptures and a baroque altarpiece of the late 17th century.

galeria.titulo: Iglesia Asunción de Nuestra Señora church

datosGenerales.descripcion:
This impressive church, built in stone in the 16th century, presents the traditional orientation to the East. In the same building, several architectural styles are to be seen, from the gothic to the neoclassical and the renaissance. 

The most Gothic parts are the nearest to the towers. It's the only remaining part of the Gothic building over which the current building was erected. Picturesque columns and archs. In the other part of the church we can see the sacristy, in neoclassical style. In the middle part we can see the stylistic evolution in the building. In the 'crucero' part we can see a Renaissance style. 

The church has also a baroque and renaissance-style altarpiece. The 18th-century organ, of classical style, is still in use and used for concerts.

datosPatrimonioCultural.estiloArtistico: Several styles, from the Romanesque to the Baroque
datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Organ and band concerts are organised in the church, among other activities.

datosGenerales.descripcion: Casa Gótica (Gothic House), named because of its peculiar decoration, meant a revolution among that period's urban residences. This building followed the traditional model of medieval houses, narrow, high and deep, only 8 metres wide and twice as much deep. The ground floor -transformed nowadays- had a main entrance and a big window that illuminated the workshop or the store. The first floor was the residence and the upper floor had a balcony and was used as storeroom or bedroom for servants. Even if it had the structure of the other houses, its peculiarity lies in the façade's decoration. In those times, in the mid-16th century, the upper floors were built in wood or by means of a wooden structure filled with checker work. But Areatza's Casa Gótica concealed that structure with plaster sheets in late Gothic style. The noble floor and the cabin were decorated with relief plaster sheets, showing circular or plant figures. And so did happen with the main floor's windows.

The church of San Martín was built over an old hermitage and has been restored and enlarged on many occasions. The building has rectangular plan and only one nave covered by a barrel vault. The main façade is situated under a depressed arch and there is also a bell tower. Inside, the visitor will see a carving of the Virgin, the only statue that bears witness to the temple's earliest stage. It should be noted that the ancient sanctuary functioned as a meeting point for the regional authorities untill the 19th century.

Located next to the Nuestra Señora de la Asunción Church, Arratabe palace was built in 1726, by order of María Isabel de Otalora, widow of Enrique Antonio de Arratabe. Materials coming from Uribe house, documented from the 16th Century, and from a palace in Eskoriatza were used for that purpose. The coat of arms located over the main entrance, for instance, came from the neighbour village and shows the coats of arms of the following families: Arratabe, Otalora, Galarza and Araotz-Lazarraga. The building hosts the new Aretxabaleta Town Council since 1986.

Since the 14th century, the Galartza Tower-House rises proudly on the sides of mount Murugain (778 m), outside the historic quarter of Aretxabaleta.

 

The lineage of the Galartza, one of the most powerful families in this vicinity, built this building, which has a square floor plan and a distinct defensive character, with the purpose of controlling the valley of Leniz.

 

Its thick walls gave shelter to the Galartza until they decided to move to the neighbouring town of Mondragon in the 19th century. On 2nd August 1990 a fire broke out, which destroyed the already very dilapidated building. The Aretxabaleta town council then took on the responsibility of restoring the historic building by boosting its reconstruction and renovation in 1997.

 

From an artistic viewpoint it preserves some interesting elements. It has masonry walls reinforced with ashlar in the corners, a main entrance in the shape of a pointed arch, small geminate windows, loopholes and pointed and ogival openings, typical of Gothic aesthetics adapted to civil architecture.

datosGenerales.nombre: Nuestra Señora de la Asunción Parish Church (Aretxabaleta)
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The construction works of the parish church began at the end of the 16th century, making the most of the presence of a hermitage in the spot. By the mid-17th century the building was finished.

 

However, the tower was built one century later following the project by Francisco de Echanove and Martín de Carrera. Finally, last came the portico. The sanctuary is located in the town centre, by the River Deba and it features only one nave, covered by quadrant vaults and traverse ribs.

 

A spherical vault, on the other hand, covers the apse. Inside the building and perfectly restored we will find the Christ of Bedarreta and the Salluete Virgin on the restrained mayor altar.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción (Elvillar)
datosGenerales.descripcion:
Construction works of the impresive church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción began in the early 16th century. It was built on a former castle, the walls of which can still be appreciated in the main portal. Its nave is extraordinarily high and has a hall plan. 

It is covered with ribbed vaults forming a star, which become even more intricate on their higher section, over the choir. Also worth mentioning is the access to the choir through a magnificent staircase with a stone handrail, covered with an oval vault in cut stone masonry and upper and lower doors decorated with pilasters. Its baptism font is a complete work of art; built on a ribbed column, it is covered in paneled decorations dating back to the 17th century. The main altarpiece is one of the most outstanding pieces of its kind in La Rioja region. 

It was built in the 16th century and gilded in the 17th century. A good number of the figures depicted narrate the life of Christ, his birth and childhood. There are also images of San Juan and Nuestra Señora del Rosario.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Concerts perodically in the church.

galeria.titulo: Church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción

datosGenerales.descripcion: This lordly house, located beside the parish church, was built in 1746 according to the inscription on its façade. It is a baroque three-floored elegant building which has masonry walls reinforced with ashlar on the corners. On its main facade the two upper floors consist of three large windows with arches lowered by pillars. It was the residence of General Tablas after he married his second wife, Concepción de Otalora. Years later it acted as culture house and, subsequently, was part of the Convento de las Agustinas convent. Nowadays the palace is the main headquarters of Caja Laboral-Euskadiko Kutxa.

This tower house was residence of the Otalora Family, one of the biggest lineages in the valley. Nowadays it operates as the Mondragón Management Development Centre and Cooperative Group. However, it keeps still some traces of its ancient splendour and power: the coat of arms, its Renaissance-style vantage point, the beautiful coffering that projects from the roof's eave, the masonry stone and the doors and windows' endings as loophole-arches.

Salinillas de Buradón is a fortified town that keeps a great part of its defence walls. Due to its location, in the border of the Rioja Alavesa region, its defence was fundamental in the Middle Ages.

 

In 1264, the nobleman don Sancho ordered the movement of its population to its current location and the contruction of these walls, for which limestone was prominently used. In the 16th and 17th centuries, on the other hand, there was an important reform and some parts of the walls were changed. Some parts were demolished and the stones were used for the new constructions. The Northern entrance, with its special reduced arch, belongs to this time.

Consisting mainly of 17 municipalities, the Valley of Léniz had no building that worked as headquarters for the local authorities. The church and the portico were used for public meetings when the bell was rung.

 

In the 17th Century, as a consequence of the split between Eskoriatza and Aretxabaleta, the former Town Hall was built on Durana, a central street.

 

Built in ashlar stone, the façade features a coat of arms with a two-headed eagle and the arms of Aretxabaleta, Gipuzkoa and Castilla-León.

 

Currently the building is home to Loramendi Euskara Elkartea (Loramendi Basque Association).

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Loramendi Euskara Elkarte arranges several cultural activities throughout the year.

datosGenerales.nombre: Nuestra Señora de la Asunción Church (Labastida)
datosGenerales.descripcion:
This majestic catholic temple, located in the town square, was built between the 16th and 18th centuries in Renaissance and Baroque styles. Its façade presents three clearly different volumes: the tower, the church itself and the new sacristy.

 

The most striking feature in the building as a whole is the façade, magnificent exponent of the architectural classicism prevailing in the 17th century. It is of Renaissance style and is sheltered below a triumphal arch with pilasters at the sides amongst which a great round arch divided in three sections opens. On the ground floor there is a double door.

 

On the inside, the exuberant main altarpiece stands out, a magnificent example of Gothic style. On the other side, in the choir, is located an amazing 17th century organ.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Organ concerts are often held

galeria.titulo: Nuestra Señora de la Asunción Church

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Labastida Town Hall is a late-Baroque style architectural gem from the 18th century.

 

The main façade, which looks out onto the square, is richly decorated. It boasts three rounded arches on the portico which leads into the building.

 

Each of these arches is decorated with three thin arch-vaults. On the first floor there are three balconies crowned with rounded arches.

 

The Labastida tourist office offers guided tours around the old town, which includes entry to the two churches (the Nuestra Señora de la Asunción and Santo Cristo churches).

The church of San Juan was built as a temple-fortress, with the necessary elements to defend the citizenship. The building shows different architectural styles. The southern facade, known as "de los abuelos", (the grandparents') combines Romanesque and Gothic styles; this was the first part to be built (end of the 12th - beginning of the 13th century) and shows a marked French influence, with some columns decorated with plant and animal motifs, and biblical stories.

 

However, most of the church was built in Gothic style in the 13th and 14th centuries. Its Latin cross plan has a transcept crossing and three apses. Pointed arches and simple cross ribbed vaults form the naves' decoration. On its walls we can also appreciate Gothic windows and rose windows.

 

The temple underwent slight modifications in the 16th century and lost its fortified character. One of the changes was the Neo-classical chapel added, dedicated to the Virgin of El Pilar, and another modification was that the tower, a medieval castle up to then, became the belfry.

 

The church's former vestry is now a museum showing liturgic objects.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Organ concerts are organized

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Miguel de Elexabeitia
datosGenerales.descripcion: The Church of San Miguel de Elexabeitia was built at the end of the Middle Ages, at the end of the 15th or the beginning of the 16th century. The main nave dates back to that period and has a Gothic tabernacle and a wooden choir at the rear. Later on, in 1621, the belfry was added above the main entrance. And the cover was built in the Baroque style's climax. Both elements were built in wood, the main characteristic of this monument. The temple keeps two polychrome wood images of San Miguel: one of them of Gothic style and the other one of Romanesque type. Likewise, there is an image of the Virgin, this one Romanesque too.

galeria.titulo: Church of San Miguel de Elexabeitia

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The palace where Arrasate-Mondragón's local authorities work dates back to the 18th century. Architect Martín Karrera started with construction works in 1756.

 

The building is of Baroque style, with masonry work. The main façade consists of five semi-circular arches that function as a entrance to the interior. The upper floor has a big wrought-iron balcony and set above eye level we will find the town's French-style coat of arms. In the interior we will see the main staircase, whose steps are made by only one stone, and the impressive carved wood in the plenary room.

Built throughout the 16th century in calle Iturrioz Street and very close to the parish church, the palace belonged to the Bañez de Artazubiaga lineage, who moved from Bedoña escaping from the submissiveness by the Guevara de Oñate. They had to burn down their lordly house in Bedoña. The main façade is masonry work and presents a coat of arms telling the aforementioned story. The Latin sentence written over the door read: "Solus labor parit virtutem; sola virtus parit honorem" (burned down for our lineage's freedom). Balconies were built in wrought iron and the house is decorated with columns. Nowadays, the palace houses private dwellings and that is why the inside cannot be visited. However, the Alto Deba Tourist Information Centre organises guided tours included in the "Conoce Debagoiena" programme (Get to know Debagoiena) around the exterior of the palace.

datosGenerales.nombre: Arrasate-Mondragón walled grounds and old town
datosGenerales.descripcion: Arrasate-Mondragón was built in the Middle Ages and was an oval-shaped town. Due to the wars between different sides spread all over the territory, a wall protected the old part of town and some traces of it are still visible. In the past, there were five gates or entrances to gain access, but nowadays, there are only three left: Portalón, Zurgin Kantoia, which is the oldest one and Kontzezino. They would be opened and closed every morning and night. Apparently, in case of fire the doors were closed so that the inhabitants would help extinguishing it. Within the walled town, there are many artistic-historic monuments, such as the parish church of San Juan Bautista, Andikano-Loiola Palace, Bañez de Artazubiaga Palace and Okendo Palace.

galeria.titulo: Arrasate-Mondragón walled grounds and old town

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Miguel de Linares
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of San Miguel de Linares is located in an open landscape presiding over the valley. It was built in the 16th century over an ancient convent. Particularly, there are two outstanding elements: the Romanesque façade and both chapels located in the nave of the sanctuary, one private and the other public. The temple was built in checker work, its nave has four stretches and a rectangular apse, and all of them crowned with a cross ribs vault. At the rear there is a square plan tower, and the high altarpiece, located in the apse, was built in polychrome wood and dates back to 1695. Its main image is the Renaissance-style image of San Miguel. The church has other valued sculptures, such as the one of the Virgin and the Child, in Rococo style, located in the centre of the altarpiece of the rosary.

datosContacto.direccion: Barrio de San Miguel de Linares

datosGenerales.descripcion: The Monterrón Palace was built in the 18th century in Herrera Baroque style. It consists of security grilles in windows and not many ornaments. The façade is a masonry work and hosts two coats of arms: one belonging to the Andikano-Zelaaa family and the other to the Aranguren-Unzueta family. Firm chains protect the former main entrance and facing the present entrance we will see a sculpture by Argentinean Marta Medici, made in 1986. Listed building since 1964, the former garden is a park nowadays where chestnuts, beeches, oaks, banana trees, and magnolias are planted, among many other species. What is more, there are also very old trees such as the giant sequoias, planted at the sides.

Balmaseda's town hall stands out because of its portico, known as the Mezquita de Balmaseda (Balmaseda's Mosque) because of its resemblance to Mudejar style. This beautiful portico is divided in five stretches with six spaces. Voussoir semi-circular arches supported by thick hexagonal pillars with facet corners form it. This beautiful Baroque building was built in the middle of the 18th Century. The main façade was built in masonry. The noble floor has five balconies with big corbels as supports, the central one is bigger than the rest and there is a coat of arms above it. The upper floor has three-centred arch windows. A complex cornice and a hipped roof crown the building.

Built in the 17th century, Okendo is a Herrera Baroque style palace consisting of a masonry façade and provided with grille-decorated balconies. Besides, it has the coat of arms of the Barrutia family. Nowadays there are private dwellings within the palace, so no visits are allowed to the interior. However, Alto Deba Tourist Information Centre organises guided tours around the exterior of the building.

The convent, church and the tutor's house form the Santa Clara architectural compound. It was built with the money left in 1675 by Mr. Juan de la Piedra y Berastegi after he came back from America. From then on the Nun Order of Saint Claire occupied the building till 1985. 

 

The façade is simple, with the main entrance under a semi-circular arch. Above it there is a niche with the image of Saint Claire and a coat of arms on each side. 

 

The interior hosts magnificent Baroque altarpieces with perfect design, trace and imagery works that date back to the 17th and 18th centuries. The choir has an organ made in 1777, one of the oldest in the territory. 

 

The building has been restored. The convent has been converted into a hostel-restaurant; the preceptoría ("Preceptorías") were schools in Spain at which aspirants to the priestly and religious life carried out their initial studies) is now a private residence and the old church now houses the Balmaseda Living Passion Interpretation Centre.

datosContacto.direccion: Campo de las monjas, 1 o Avenida Encartaciones, 2

datosGenerales.nombre: Hermitage of San Roque de Kolitza
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The hermitage of San Roque is located on top of Kolitza Mountain, trying to stand still over a cliff at a sea level altitude of 880 metres.

 

Even if it is mentioned already in 1111, the present hermitage dates back to the 13th Century, when Cistercian style prevailed. Built in masonry, it has only one rectangular nave, with barrel vault and apse. The main entrance is located under a semi-circular arch, with three archivolts supported by figured corbels.

 

The tower has only one bell and a stone cross on top.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: A procession is held the first Saturday 40 days after Easter.

galeria.titulo: Hermitage of San Roque de Kolitza

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Condestable's Tower is a bit aloof of the rest of the settlement, which is more populated.

 

This place is a bit isolated, and was by the old path leading to the salt mines. The name of the Condestable's Tower (Torre Condestable) is related to the kinship that the founders of this tower, the Solórzano family, had with the Velasco family, another noble family of Castile. This tower was built around the same time as the Torre de Orgaz, that is, at the end of the 14th century or during the 15th century. The tower shows slightly rectangular foundations (12.30 x 11.20 metres), the walls are 1.50 metres wide and the tower is 20 metres tall. The tower was built with very well cut ashlar, in rectangular lines and with funerary signs. The tower is empty inside.

 

Type of monument: Tower-house. Period: Middle Ages (14th and 15th centuries). Observations: The tower cannot be visited inside. Car park: Cars can be parked in the surroundings.

"La Encartada" beret company was established in 1892 by Marcos Arena, in co-operation with an English textile company. They made berets mainly. The whole production came from the factory: beginning with the acquisition of raw material and wool spinning, until berets were made up. Several buildings form the compound: the factory itself, the workers' dwellings, a hermitage and the residence of the person in charge. The factory is a four-storey rectangular firm building, with smaller spaces attached to it. It has great windows too. In its interior there is well-preserved and highly valuable machinery, mostly original, dating back to the 19th century. Nowadays the building is home to the Textile Museum.

galeria.titulo: La Encartada Barets Museum. Photo: Xabier Armendariz
La Encartada Barets Museum. Photo: Xabier Armendariz
La Encartada Barets Museum. Photo: Xabier Armendariz
La Encartada Barets Museum. Photo: Xabier Armendariz

datosGenerales.nombre: Torre de los Orgaz de Fontecha
datosGenerales.descripcion:
This tower-house of the Orgaz is a group formed by the wall, the tower and the palace. The tower was built in the late 14th century with sandstone well treated. It's rectangular and in its façades appear several kinds of windows.

 

The palace was erected in the 16th century, when the group lost its defence task. This work was done with sandstone and was given a rectangular form. The main entrance to the palace is an arch help up by gothic columns. In the late 19th century, probably after a time of neglect, this building started to be used as a country house. Years later, in the 20th century, the settlement was totally abandoned, and now it hosts the Escuela Taller Micaela Portilla Training School that, apart from the Training Programmes, is in charge of the restoration and renovation of the building itself.

 

Type of monument: Tower and palace. Period: Middle Age (14th and 15th centuries). Observations: Currently, it hosts the Escuela Taller Micaela Portilla that renovates the building. Visits are not allowed.

galeria.titulo: Torre de los Orgaz de Fontecha tower

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Labraza is a village located at the top of a hill. It was built in the Middle Ages and, for its defence, it got surrounded by a wall.

 

The king Sancho VII of Navarre awarded the town the title of "village" in 1196 and ordered that the Western borders of Navarre should be watched by the Labraza people. 

 

With the passage of time, the wall has integrated into the houses, becoming a part of their walls.

datosPatrimonioCultural.horario:
MONDAY TO FRIDAY


From 10:00 h. at 2:00 p.m. and from 16:00 h. at 7:00 p.m.


SATURDAYS


From 10:00 h. at 2:00 p.m. and from 5:00 p.m. at 7:00 p.m.


SUNDAYS AND HOLIDAYS


10:45 h. at 2:00 p.m.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Nuestra Señora de la Peña de Faido
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Virgen de la Peña hermitage, located in Faido, is regarded as one of the oldest Christian churches best preserved in Euskadi in these days. It's been declared a National Monument.

 

It was built in an artificial cave dating from the Middle Ages, exactly in the second stock of the Kruzia caves. The building falls into two parts: the lobby (inside a building incrusted in the rock) and the temple itself (excavated into the rock).

 

The entrance to the lobby is reached going through an arch. Inside, we'll find a mural representing the Stations of the Cross. Getting into the rock, we'll enter a temple built taking advantage of a former pre-Romanesque hermitage.

 

The altarpiece is of white rock (built in the 18th century). An image of the Virgen de la Peña, dating from the 13th-14th centuries, is kept there.

Three Roman semi-circular arches function as an entrance to the black stone ashlar building. Architect José Lizardi designed the building.

 

It consists of two upper floors presenting two wrought-iron balconies supported by corbels and made by Gregorio Aguirre de Elgoibar. Finished in 1760, the building housed a school, a grain storage building and an inn. A golden cross-and-ball on a pyramid by Pablo Etxebarria de Asteasu crowns the ceiling.

 

The council was inaugurated in 1762 and the façade's upper part displays a coat of arms chiselled in 1865 and painted in 1890 by Crespulo Gonzalez de Tolosa.

The Murgia family was, from the Middle Ages, the most powerful clan in Astigarraga and its surroundings. Its palace, tower house in the beginning, rests over a hill that dominates the basin of River Urumea. 

Murgia Palace is a remarkable construction of rectangular plan consisting of a ground floor and two floors covered with a hipped roof. It still keeps most part of the old ahslar wall with joints. The building caught fire in the 16th and 19th centuries due to several conflicts that devastated the country and had to be restored many times. 

It was restored for the last time by the end of the previous century. Wooden vantage points of Gothic style attached at the sides, the unusual imperial staircases and the gardens preceding also underwent restoration works. The coats of arms of Murgia family is displayed over the main entrance. 

It is home to a historical archive and a library of great value.

datosGenerales.nombre: The Parish Church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The parish church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción -also known as Santa María de Murguía- is located on a hill that is nowadays known as Markesmendi. Since time immemorial it has been linked to the patronage of the Murgia family, whose lordly house is just below the temple. 

It is thought that the building dates back to the 12th Century but afterwards it underwent several reforms. The temple's plan is Latin cross shaped and ribbed vaults form the ceiling. The choir is placed over a big arch. Finally, its tower, 25 metres high, hosts the bells and a clock brought from Bordeaux in 1840. 

The small church was constructed in ashlar masonry, a Latin cross plan with two naves of two rectangular sections covered by groin vaults supported by pilasters and a crossing with octagonal apse. The sacristy, the baptistery and a large wooden portico are attached to the building. Murgia lineage has a coat of arms carved on the wall over the access. The retable was built during the last Carlist War being replaced by another one in 1888 from the church of San Vicente in Donostia / San Sebastián. 

Some images of the previous altarpiece have been kept. The Sagardoaren Lurraldea association organises guided tours in Astigarraga throughout the year, which also includes this monument.

The Trespuentes Bridge connects the two riverbanks of the River Zadorra. On the bridge, in the way that leads to town, we will notice the old path built by the Romans. T

he bridge consists of thirteen round arches and it was constructed with pieces of stone and mortar, except for those stones that bear the arch. 

The following restorations gave way to stone parapets on both sides of the bridge.

Salvatierra-Agurain is a medieval village and, as such, was walled for several centuries.

 

In that period the village had only three streets: Mayor, which comprises the most interesting houses from an artistic standpoint; Carnicería and Zapatari, which hosted the village's butchers and shoemakers respectively. Nowadays these streets form the old and artistic part of the village.

 

There, we will find a good number of monumental buildings, such as the fortress-churches of San Juan and Santa María, the Casa de las Viudas (Widows' House), the oldest civilian building in the municipality, the houses of the Begoña, the Azkarraga or the Bustamante families, the Diezmo house and the Olbeas de San Juan.

It was originally conceived as a fortress. The temple that we know today originated at the end of the 15th century and mainly in the 16th, due to the fire that broke out in Salvatierra in 1564 and which destroyed the previous church. It is a rectangular Gothic style temple, with a tower which consists of two different parts.

 

In the cruise section there is a 17th century belfry and at the base of the tower there is a pointed arch door with a moulding. The gateway and the bell tower are both of Baroque style. The complex is very austere and its inner layout is of a Gothic style from the first half of the 16th century. It consists of a rectangular base with three naves of different heights and a straight ambulatory.

 

The main altarpiece is a work begun by Mateo de Zabala in 1646 and continued by Pedro de Obrel in 1650. It is classified as classicist Baroque and was completed towards 1660. The image of the Andra Mari de Egileor of the 14th century is kept in the sacristy. Also noteworthy is the organ, located in the chancel. It was built by Juan Monturus in the 19th century.

 

Guided tours of the historic quarter of Agurain take place every Sunday at 13:00 and on Thursdays in July and August. Registration at the tourist office.

Located to the north of the town, near the north entrance to Salvatierra, the church of Santa María is a temple-fortress that once formed part of the wall. It was built between the late 15th and early 16th century on top of an earlier church, and has excellent stalls. It belongs to the late Gothic.

 

The core is rectangular, with three naves. The central nave stands out, wider and taller than the rest. The sacristy is from the late 17th century, spacious, simple and with a beautiful balcony. The main entrance is Gothic, from the early 16th century, and is topped by a 17th century steeple. Inside, the front of the wonderful, richly decorated Plateresque choir is dominated by a large crest of Emperor Charles V. The main altarpiece is a masterpiece by Renaissance artist Lope de Larrea.

 

The church of Santa María also has outstanding images such as the Virgin of the Rosary, Mary Magdalene and Andra Mari de Sailurtegi. The organ is an outstanding piece from 1806, by Manuel Antonio de Carvajal.

 

Guided tours of the historic quarter of Agurain take place every Sunday at 13:00 and on Thursdays in July and August. Registration at the tourist office.

The monastery of Santa María was built by the Cistercian order in the 13th century and it is set in the southern side of the mountains that mark the boundaries with Oñati. Nowadays, it is one of Alava's youth hostels and its interior has been fitted out to lodge youth groups. It seems to be one of the first monasteries founded by this religious order, which preserves the bull by Pope Gregorio IX issued in 1232, where the monastery's antiquity is confirmed. Up to the 19th century, it had its own parish church. Worth seeing are the abbesses' cementery and the two-storey cloister, with 6 arches on its side and its upper gallery closed with rectangular windows. The convent has an extraordinary interest from the archeologic and anthropologic point of view, because of the remains it sits on. However, there are no traces of the first medieval construction that stood here, being the oldest vestiges from the 15th century.The complex is divided into two parts: the church of Nuestra Señora de Barría and the Cistercian monastery. The church is a temple from the late 15th century and has a rectangular plan.

The organ of the church of San Martín de Tours in Ataun is one of the best known and appreciated in Gipuzkoa. It was built in 1761 by Lorenzo de Arrazola, born in Oñati. Despite the fact that there are over 150 organs in the territory, most of them belong to the 19th or 20th centuries. Only seven Baroque organs exist in the world and this is one of them, which is to be found in Ataun. Throughout the year the organ shows its good condition in festivals. The two most important performances are as follows: the Barroco Aire Festival, which is held in Ataun and Ordizia, and the Baroque Organ in Ataun in July.

datosContacto.direccion: Iglesia San Martín de Tours, barrio San Martín

datosGenerales.nombre: Nuestra Señora de la Asunción Church (Tuesta)
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The temple of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción de Tuesta is one of the best examples of the transition from Romanesque to Gothic style in the province of Alava.

 

Its date of construction is unknown, but it is believed it was erected at the end of the 12th century or beginning of the 13th century. Its façade, in Romanesque style, presents magnificent decorations depicting Bible passages. Its portico was built much later, in 1795. Inside, stands out the vault covering the church; despite its reduced dimensions, it is groined for strength. The main altarpiece is placed in a chapel facing South.

 

It was carved in the 16th century and its central image portraits the assumption of the Virgin Mary. Another of the temple's treasures is the sculpture of the Virgen Blanca, which dates back to 1300 approximately.

The San Adrián tunnel is part of the inland Saint James' Way and one of the beauty spots of the Aizkorri-Aratz nature park. It is a tunnel running through the rock of a mountain, in a spectacular setting.

 

It is also a historic place, through which pilgrims, merchants and kings have passed over the centuries.

 

It is only about 70 metres long, but inside it houses a chapel with the same name, reached by a mediaeval road which clearly shows its importance as a communication link in the past.

 

The two villages closest to the tunnel are Zalduondo (in Álava province) and Zegama (in Gipuzkoa), the tunnel lying on the border between the two provinces.

 

The way from the village of Zalduondo is via a metalled road that goes to the locality of Zumarraundi (known as “Las Petroleras”). It stretches for some five kilometres, in a patchy state of repair, not without difficulty as the route climbs.

 

The way from Zegama is along a high, steeply-sloping footpath through the Aizkorri hills.

The Archivo Histórico Provincial de Alava (Alava History Archives) was declared historic monument because of the value of its collection.

 

The archive was created by a decree issued on November 12th, 1931, with an aim to preserve and disseminate notarial protocols over 100 years old. Later on, other types of documents (the oldest date from the 13th century) and, at present, manages the documentation produced by notaries and by the State's public admininstration in the province of Alava. It also collects private archives. It is possible to consult the documents kept in its deposits. We can find there any kind of document created by public institutions and documentation belonging to the Real Sociedad Bascongada de Amigos del País, Universidad de Oñati and to several lineages of the territory.

 

The Archivo Histórico Provincial de Alava has occupied four different premises along its history, and on July 2004 it finally settled in its definite location in the university distric of the capital, between the strudents' residence and the Business and trade studies faculty.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: It hosts a biennial exhibition.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Vitoria-Gasteiz' old part, the first settlement in the city, still preserves its original almond-shaped medieval plan, which dates back to more than 8 centuries ago, when Sancho VI "The wise" founded the city.

It is located on a hill dominated by the Cathedral of Santa María. This Gothic temple is undergoing great restoration works and archaeological excavations, which can be visited by the public. Drawing the most recognizable city skyline are, as well as Santa Maria Cathedral, the towers of the churches of San Miguel, San Vicente and San Pedro.

The names of its streets recall the artisan traders who used to work and live there (Correría, Herrería, Zapatería, Cuchillería, Pintorería...) and host the oldest and most singular buildings in the city. Behind the cathedral, for instance, visitors will be able to admire the Portalón, a nice medieval brick inn, and the tower of Anda.

In the heart of the old medieval quarter, two magnificent Reinassance palaces stand out: the Escoriza-Esquivel palace and the Montehermoso palace, the latter now refurbished into a cultural centre.

Also in the old part, we find the Casa del Cordón, a house with a beautiful facade, the Bendaña palace (Bibat Museum) of Gothic-Renaissance style, the church of San Vicente, Villasuso palace and Los Arquillos viewpoint.

The house was built at the end of the 12th century or the beginning of the 13th century, that is to say the construction is older than the town itself.

 

It was originally built for defensive purposes. However, in 1456 King Enrique IV ordered to lop all the tower houses so they turn it into an ordinary building. In the period of side battles the Balda lineage joined the Gamboa side.

 

The main façade's coat of arms dates back to that period. The house was the birthplace of several warriors and Saint Ignatius Loyola's mother's, Doña Marina Sáez de Licona y Balda. That is the reason why a chapel was built later on, consecrated to the saint. Untill the 16th century these walls hosted the parish church in town. Later on, the present parish church was built in lands belonging to the Bastarrica family.

 

The legend has it that the priest was fatally wounded by the Baldas while transferring the Holy Sacrament's image.

Idiakez Tower, also known as Etxe Beltza, impacts on the visitors, for its walls are blackened. Many stories revolve around the house. It is said that it was built in the Middle Ages as a residence for the Idiakez family, in Gothic style and its main façade still keeps the family's coat of arms: an ox going through a tree.

 

The marriage of the first Carlist King, Carlos V de Borbón, with the Beira Princess was ratified in this place. A few years later, in the II Carlist War, the house was besieged and burnt down. That is the reason why its walls are blackened -thereby the name of the house.

 

Outside we can find the Barricas fountain, dating back to 1831. Nowadays the palace belongs to the Dukes of Granada de Ega and it is not open to the public.

Artabene is an ordinary type of farmhouse in the valleys of Arratia and Alto Nervión. It was built following the traditional technique in Bizkaia, which consists of building a skeleton of pillars and, later on, filling with walls the spaces between them. The farmhouse was built in two stages: two thirds of the front in the 16th century and the rear part in the beginning of the 19th century. The oldest part of the house is rectangular. Oak posts arise from the floor to the roof and are visible on the main façade. The main façade is divided into three floors, the ground one is built in checker work, the first floor with a complex wooden structure and the last one with mortise and tenon joint-tables. The layout of Artabene, at present, dedicates the ground floor to stables and the two thirds of the front are occupied and the rest is used as a barn. Access to the first floor is gained by means of an outer staircase.

In the beginning, Floreaga Palace was built in stone and Gothic style. After the towers' destruction by Pedro IV, its owner, Pedro Sánchez de Zuazola, built it again in brick and Mudejar style. The sober door giving access to the main gallery, the building's mullions and an ogee arch on the eastern façade are remarkable features. From 1677 onwards the house came under the administration of Garcíez Counts and lost its original splendour. The famous pelota player Atano III was born in 1904 in this palace, which as time went by turned into a farm. Nowadays the building hosts the restaurant known as Restaurante Joseba.

Beautiful Baroque palace built in the middle of the 18th century. Corresponding to the innovative mentality of the Age of Enlightenment, a theoretical treatise on architecture was developed, that is the reason why the building is unique. The Insausti Palace was the birthplace of Xabier de Munibe, Count of Peñaflorida, who was founder of the Academia de Azkoitia and Real Sociedad Bascongada de Amigos del País (Royal Basque Society of Friends of the Country), later in 1764. Following considerable restoration works, Insausti Palace reopened its doors in 2006 converted into the Real Sociedad Bascongada de Amigos del País. Offices, meeting rooms, lecture halls and a room for Historical Memory make up the building. What is more, it is also home to the International Institute Xabier de Munibe and Iraurgi Lantzen offices, entity working on the development of Urola Medio.

The Virgen Blanca square lies under this gothic temple built between the 14th and the 16th centuries, over the remains of a former hermitage.

The architectural gothic and renaissance styles merge in this rectangular-shaped construction with three naves covered with special supports. Inside, there is a big altarpiece, of baroque style, created by the sculptor Gregorio Fernández.

This church is one of the most famous in the city, since Our Lady of la Virgen Blanca, patron saint of the city, is worshipped in it. At the same time, the image of this church is very well-known, given that from its bell tower comes down "Celedón" every 4th of August, which starts the Vitoria's major celebrations.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Music concerts are played inside the church.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Casa del Cordón, called so due to the Franciscan stone cordon surrounding one of the entrance arches, is a curious example of the civil art in the Middle Ages. This house was ordered by the merchant Pedro Sánchez Bilbao in the 15th century.

 

There is a valuable tower inside the house and, in addition, it has maintained all its original elements as a trading house (casa de comercio) of the Middle Ages. Furthermore, this house has been one of the few civil buildings that keeps a gothic, star-shaped vault. The main façade has two big archs.

 

This building has witnessed great events throughout history. Adriano de Utrech, for instance, got to know in this house that he had been elected Pope (Pope Adrian VI).

 

It now houses the Vital Foundation.

datosPatrimonioCultural.horario:
Monday to Thursday: 8.30 a.m. - 2 p.m. / 4.30 p.m. - 7 p.m.

Friday: 8.30 a.m. - 2 p.m.

datosGenerales.nombre: Convent and cloister of San Francisco
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The convent of San Francisco is one of the oldest sanctuaries of Bizkaia, according to existing documents. Earl Tello and his wife Juana de Lara ordered its construction in 1357. Works finished at the end of the 16th century.

 

In the following centuries the building had different usages: barracks, jail, school and court, among others. Moreover, the cloister served as a market for several years. Nowadays, a church, the cloister and part of the convent, restored thoroughly, forms the compound.

 

The church has only one nave, polygonal apse and a groin vault crowns it. The nave is illuminated by means of pointed-arch openings and the main entrance has flower decoration.

 

However, the cloister is the compound's main element. It opens towards the courtyard by means of pointed arches supported by pillars decorated with three small columns. All four corners have a segmental arch supported in corbels decorated with figurative motifs: friars praying, singing or preaching.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Special concerts at Christmas time.

galeria.titulo: Convent and cloister of San Francisco

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Villasuso Palace is located next to the church of San Miguel, in the well-known Machete Square, right in the city centre. Its construction was ordered by Martín de Salinas, ambassador of Emperor Charles I, around 1539.

The building is unique in the shape of U, due to its adaptation to the wall and the unevenness of the land. The factory wall is made of small hewn stones whereas the façade, the coat of arms and the frames of balistralias of ashlar. In the past the main façade led to Villasuso Square, on the highest part of the area. There, the coat of arms of the Salinas Family and an entrance with lintels and columns can be seen. Today, the palace can be reached through the Machete Square. 

The City Council purchased the palace and has adapted it to give conferences, hold exhibitions and social events.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Guided tours in summer, Easter and long weekends. Contact the Vitoria-Gasteiz Tourist Office for further information (+34 945 161 598)

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Fernán López de Escoriaza, the doctor of the English King Henry VIII, and his wife, Victoria de Anda y Esquivel, ordered to build the Escoriaza-Esquivel palace in the mid-16th century. Due to its architectonic and decorative richness, it is one of the best examples of the civil Renaissance-style architecture.

 

The palace, built with masonry stone in the heart of the Old Quarter of Vitoria-Gasteiz, is arranged around a square yard surrounded by a double series of arches group of arches placed on top of three of its sides and a staircase. The columns have many decorated elements. It is also remarkable that the main façade, placed opposite a little square, features a Plateresque-style part containing a bust of the landlord and his wife.

 

Nowadays this building belongs to Vitoria-Gasteiz City Council. Guided tours are offered in Easter Week, summer and long weekends. Contact the Vitoria-Gasteiz Tourist Office for further information (+34 945 161 598)

This awesome church was the last one to be built in the old part: its construction dates back to the end of the 15th century and the beginning of the 16th century, and it presents Renaissance and Gothic features. 

The church has three naves covered at the same height by cross ribbed vaults and intermediate arches. Inside, it is worth mentioning the chapel of the Santa Cruz (La Milagrosa), bearing the imperial coat of arms of courtisan Ortuño Ibañez de Aguirre, and the choir and the chapel of El Carmen, with late Renaissance elements. 

Only some remains of the old fortress have been preserved, such as some of its tower's wooden framed structure (over the temple's naves), which, no doubt, deserves a visit.

The Palacio-Casa del Santo palace is located in the centre of Armentia, in the highest part of the city.

 

The legend says that San Prudencio de Armentia was born here, but the current house has really nothing to do with the worshipped saint. It was built in 1806 by Juan José Díaz de Espada and Fernández de Landa, bishop of La Habana, and during many years it's been the residence of the Díaz de Espada family. The architect Justo Antonio de Olaguibel was in charge of this work, built in a neoclassical style. It is a square-based, two-storey house covered by a roof divided in four parts. The most interesting element is the main façade, built in a perfectly worked ashlar. The façade comprises two big columns that divide the façade in three parts. In the middle, above the door and surrounded by the sculpted stone in different ways, we can see the image of San Prudencio flanked by two angels. It was recognised as an Artistic-Historic Monument in 2002. Type of monument: Palace. Style: Neoclassical.

 

Period: 19th century. Observations: The building belongs to the Regional Council of Álava and is not open to the public.

This Gothic building was erected attached to the city walls, which explains why its main portal and entrance was located on one side up to the 19th century, when a new entrance was added. Most of this beautiful building was constructed in the 14th century. Its plan forms a Latin cross with an asymmetric apse. 

The old portal (in calle Herrería) is one of the most impressive sculptural complexes in the Basque Autonomous Region. It is presided by an image of the Virgin accompanied by Saint James and Saint Peter and, on the other side, Saint Paul and Saint John. Saint Peter presides the tympanum. All of these figures were elegantly and exquisitely carved. In the interior, we find ogival arches, Gothic windows and cross ribbed vaults. 

The abundance of heraldic motifs in the church as decoration is an outstanding feature of this temple.

datosContacto.direccion: Calle Fundadora de las Siervas de Jesús

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Cape Matxitxako has two lighthouses, the old one is not used any more. Nowadays, only the new one operates.

 

The old lighthouse, whose tower is the unique element that remains standing, was inaugurated in 1852 and kept operating until 1909. It was built in masonry with ashlar from Duranguesado quarries. 

The current lighthouse is situated 110 metres from the old tower. The first started functioned when the latter was taken out of service. The building consists of the lighthouse keepers' house, the storeroom and the stock depot. It has rectangular plan, the central body has two floors and the lateral bodies have one floor only. 

The main entrance is a semi-circular arch. The tower is located at the end, with octagonal plan and built in checker work with a nice cast iron dome that hosts the lighthouse's light.

To get here:

take the BI 3101 road from Bermeo, leaving the town via the district of Arene. When you reach the gasworks you will find an area on the right where you can park. From there take the path down to the lighthouse, but be aware that the climb back up on the return journey is quite steep.

datosPatrimonioCultural.periodo: The old lighthouse dates back to the 19th century and the new one dates back to the 20th century.

datosGenerales.descripcion: The Augustin Zulueta Palace was built for Ricardo Augusti in 1912 according to the style and taste of the then most powerful families in the city. The authors were the same that built the new cathedral: the architects Julián Apraiz and Javier de Luque. In 1941, the Regional Council of Álava purchased it to base the Fine Arts Museum and, in 1962, it was declared Historic-Artistic Monument. In this museum, there is an exhibition of Spanish art of the 18th and 19th centuries, as well as a selection of Basque 'costumbrismo' ranging from the last quarter of the 19th century and the first half of the 20th century. Surrounded by a garden, it is an eclectic building that has been enlarged to host several works in it. In this way, the museum falls into three very well differenciated parts: the main building (the palace), another part enlarged in the 1960's and a newly constructed building where the access to the art gallery is located.

datosContacto.direccion: Paseo de Fray Francisco de Vitoria, 8

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Exhibitions, conferences, workshops...

datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of Santa Eufemia was probably constructed in the 13th century and reconstructed at the end of the 15th. It is Bermeo's oldest church and it is located presiding over the old port. Of Gothic style, as can be seen in the windows, doors and the vault's nerves. It has one nave only, there is a choir at one end and the apse is polygonal with two chapels. Beside the second chapel the visitor will find the sepulchre of the Mendoza family, built in Gothic style. The tower, built in 1783, has a pinnacle-decorated dome. The Lords of Biscay swore the Laws in this church, declared Historic and Artistic Monument in 1995.

The church of Santa María is one of the most significant buildings in Bizkaia's Neo-classical architecture. Judge Colón de Larreategi ordered its construction in 1783 but works did not began till 1823. Architect Silvestre Pérez designed it and it was inaugurated in 1858. The church has Latin cross shape, with a semi-circular apse and two towers attached to the main façade. A peculiar vault covers the central part and the rest is crowned with barrel vaults, except the apse, which was covered by a cul-de-four, and the lateral chapels, crowned with groin vaults. The Neo-classical portico is worth mentioning too, because it has a triangular pediment supported by a series of Dorian columns. Inside, the high altarpiece and those in the angles are quite remarkable. The carving of the Asunción de Nuestra Señora is from Roman Times and it was taken, probably, from the old church located in that place.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: The Music Week in august

datosGenerales.descripcion: The Arch of San Juan is the only one that remains standing out of the seven arches that the village's walls had. The doors connected the village with the main routes. The gate was named San Juan since it leads to the hermitage of San Juan de Gaztelugatxe. It was the main gate because above it there is a tower-shaped building. The gate dates back to the 14th century. It opens to the village's inner side by means of a segmented arch; meanwhile, there is a pointed arch facing outwards. Among them appears the gap used to close down the village's gate. Above the arch there is a niche with an image of San Juan.

Ercilla tower, which belonged to Ercilla family, is located over Bermeo's old port. It is the only one that remains standing out of the 30 found in the past.

 

It was built at the end of the 15th century and even if its structure has some defense elements, its character is more or less that of a residence. The tower consists of six-side uneven plan and hexagonal roof. Its side walls give testimony to its fortress nature.

 

The main façade was built in sandstone masonry, as is the case of another side, even if this one is more irregular. The rest are built in checker work. It was declared historic monument in 1944 and the regional council of Bizkaia bought it three years later. Restored in 1948, since then, it hosts the Fisheman's Museum.

The church of San Juan Evangelista dates back to the 12th century, but it has undergone many restorations since those days, the main one in 1550, which defined its present Renaissance style appearance. It consists of a long nave divided into four stretches, with a Gothic cross ribbed vault. The church's most valuable feature is the choir, at the rear. Two segmented arches finishing in a central column support it. Besides, it has a magnificent parapet with small columns. The temple has a spectacular altarpiece carved in walnut wood. Outstanding are its size and the stories it depicts, painted in 1704, not a common feature in the churches of this province.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Concerts are held in the church at Christmas and during the rest of the year.

datosGenerales.nombre: Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de Andikoa
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de Andikoa is a Gothic temple. It was built in 1560 and the nave divided into three stretches. Harmonious and proportioned, its walls were built in golden coloured stone masonry. The apse hosts the vestry and the portico is located on the side of the church. 

The church has no tower, but a belfry for bells, located on one side too. Inside, at the rear, two arches and a column support the choir. It is a replica of the choir in the church of San Juan Evangelista, also located in Berriz. 

The altarpiece is worth agazing at too; made in polychromed wood and in a particular type of Baroque called Churrigueresque style, some of its architectural elements tend already towards Rococo. The sanctuary of Andikoa was restored in 1949.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Two festivities are celebrated in this sanctuary, the Purificación de Nuestra Señora on February 2nd, and the Ascensión del Señor a los cielos.

galeria.titulo: Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de Andikona

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The old Enparan tower of Azpeitia dates back to 1320. It was the Enparan family's residence, relatives of the Oñacino side. Many of those born in this house served in Castille's Court.

 

King Enrique IV of Castille ordered the dismantling of every tower house in Gipuzkoa in order to put an end to side battles and the house was restored in 1535, pulling down the building's upper part. However, it did not have its present appearance till 1750.

 

Nowadays it is a rectangular Gothic house formed by three bodies: the central one has square plan, higher than the other two, and has pinnacles on the roof. Nowadays, the building hosts the Town Library but its rooms also hold other activities, such as civil weddings.

datosGenerales.nombre: Convent and church of Hermanas Concepcionistas Franciscanas
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Convent of Concepcionist Franciscan Sisters was built in the 16th century very close to Enparan Tower-House.

 

The church is the main monument in the compound, particularly all the rich polychrome decoration of its domes and vault, built at the end of the 19th or the beginning of the 20th century. The dome, for instance, shows a fugue-like balustrade with flowerpots full of varied flowers. Likewise, the church keeps a veritable treasure, an image of Jesus Christ made by Jerónimo de Larrea.

 

The church opens its doors only for religious services, whereas the convent remains closed.

galeria.titulo: Convent and church of Hermanas Concepcionistas Franciscanas

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The church of San Severino dates back to the 15th century, and is located in Balmaseda's main square.

 

The building is of Gothic style, but due to some restorations made in the 18th century visitors will admire several Baroque elements. Its interior is Gothic. It is divided in three naves and the central one finishes in a polygonal apse with elegant stained glass windows. Besides, there is a Cavaillé - Coll organ dating back to the end of the 19th century. The chapel of the Santo Cristo is the most important one, with a Plateresque altarpiece.

 

The outer part and the tower were restored in 1730, which is why the building shows several Baroque elements.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Concerts are celebrated at Christmas and in the spring.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Bilbao's City Hall was built at the end of 19th century, in the ancient location of San Agustín convent. Architect Joaquín Rucoba was the project's head.

This monumental building was built in eclectic language, combining classicist origins of different origin, mainly the 3rd Republic's French public architecture.

In the main façade stands out the eight-column and three-arch arcade. This great balcony is crowned by a pediment hosting a clock and finished in a tower. Beside the arcade, two side-openings confer verticality to the building. Sculptures, busts and statues decorate its façades. Luxury and magnificence prevail also inside, as can be seen in the plenary room, the hall and staircase and the reception room.

The latter was built in Neo-Arab style and the other two in Neo-Renaissance style.

datosGenerales.nombre: Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de la Encina
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de la Encina is one of Alava's most amazing and most attended temples.

 

According to an inscription found in the building, it was erected in 1498. The building has three naves that show Gothic and Renaissance features.

 

The Gothic style is to be found in the cross ribbed vaults that cover the naves, supported by ogival arches. The vaults over the side naves are polychromed. The Renaissance style, on the contrary, is shown in the choir and the Santo Cristo chapel, built by Pedro de Oribe Salazar.

 

Finally, the main altarpiece, of Spanish-Flemish Gothic style, accommodates the venerated image of Nuestra Señora de la Encina. The temple was built by a holm oak which is now 500 years old. Legend has it that the Virgin appeared on this spot.

 

Type: Sanctuary. 

Style: Gothic-Renaissance.

Period: 16th century. 

Car park: There is free parking space near the Sanctuary.

galeria.titulo: Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de la Encina

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Artziniega's old part presents the typical features of a medieval village built over a hillock to take advantage of the relief, and contains three main streets going from East to West: calle de Arriba street, with the church at one of its ends, calle del Medio, and calle de Abajo streets.

 

However, the main constructions still standing nowadays are Baroque and Renaissance palaces dating back to the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. The ones built in the 19th century are very peculiar because they were built around a garden courtyard.

 

Among the different buildings of interest, some worth mentioning are: the so-called "torre de la calle Correo" tower, from the 15th century; the Torreón de los Ortíz Molinillo de Velasco tower (16th c.); the convent of the Agustinas order - erected on top of the old Monteano y Oribe Salazar tower-, and the parish church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción, typical 18th century building.

datosGenerales.nombre: Hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Olatz
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Olatz is located halfway on the road between Azpeitia and the Sanctuary of Loiola.

 

This temple has been tightly linked to the Loiola family for years, for they were its patrons: Saint Ignatius, for instance, had a special devotion to this virgin, whom he used to pray. Moreover, this place was the meeting point for Gipuzkoa's General Assembly till the 18th century. The temple dates back to the 13th century.

 

The main door is semi-circular and in the interior, the vault and the wooden choir stand out. However, its main gem is the Virgin's Gothic carving, made in polychrome wood.

galeria.titulo: Hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Olatz

datosGenerales.nombre: The hermitage of Santa María Magdalena
datosGenerales.descripcion: The hermitage of Santa María Magdalena is located on the outskirts of the town, near the road coming from the coast. It dates back to the 14th century and, since then, part of the building functions as a hospital for pilgrims. The church, as is the case of others in Azpeitia, was tightly linked to Saint Ignatius of Loiola for he taught catechism there. In terms of architecture, the main façade consists of a portico with three semi-circular arches on the ground floor and brick decoration on the main floor. Restored in 1921 on the occasion of the 4th centenary of San Ignatio's wound in Pamplona-Iruña.

datosContacto.descripcionNumeroTelefono: Parish Church of San Sebastián de Soreasu

galeria.titulo: The hermitage of Santa María Magdalena

datosGenerales.descripcion:
In the 16th century the Dominican order chose this location to built their convent. Nowadays the compound is formed by the church and cloister, which host the Museo Diocesano de Arte Sacro, or sacred art museum.

 

Originally the temple had only one nave covered by a star-shaped vault, aligned crossing and several chapels to both sides of the nave. However, in the 20th century the chapels were transformed into naves.

 

The cloister has been renovated on several occasions but it still maintains two galleries with stone and pointed arched-arcades. The upper rooms exhibit the museum's paintings and sculptures.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: The convent houses the Museo de Arte Sacro of Bilbao, the city's sacred art museum.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Architect Antonio Zobaran was responsible for the project of this 20th century monumental building (1942-1953). From the very beginning the building was planned as the headquarters for the State Treasury delegation, so it was projected as offices building.

 

The building's majesty concurs with the style used for public buildings in Franco's period: the style recovered some features of the classicism and 16th century's imperial styles.

 

This way, in the main façade we'll find a wide repertoire of classicist decoration (pediments, corbels) and balconies for public functions.

The works of the church of the Santos Juanes began in 1622 and finished 20 years later. The Jesuit Padre Ramírez was responsible for the project. However, after the floods in 1983 the church had to be restored. We'd like to stress the main façade, designed in three streets or stretches.

The middle one is wider and higher and is connected to the other by means of wings. The access to the interior is done through a semi-circular arch, crowned by two Dorian columns that support a pediment. The cover followed that period's style: vault decorated with geometric forms. 

As regards its furniture, the high altarpiece is outstanding, with its Solomonic columns decorated with grapefruits. Likewise, there is a 16th century image of Christ and a sculpture of La Dolorosa dating back to the 18th century.

This temple was opened in 1756, thirteen years after its building began directed by Loyola Ignacio Ibero master builder. His proposal was original for the period: a Greek cross-shaped church within a square and covered by a dome. 

Dead angles in the corners are devoted to chapels and vestry. From outside the magnificent dome covering the temple has chamfered prism shape, even if the belfry placed in the middle of the main façade disguises its presence. The façade includes the main entrance and both towers on its side. 

The main entrance's tympanum stands out because of its bronze relief. Inside, we find five awesome Rococo altarpieces by Juan Pascual de Mena.

The church of San Pedro in Deusto was projected in 1515. It is a one-nave temple with three uneven stretches. 

The building was made completely in masonry and late Gothic style, whose characteristics can be seen in the columns' decoration, the openings and the main facade door. However, the belfry and the choir were built later, following different styles. Inside we'll find three interesting altarpieces, the main one in Renaissance style.

datosGenerales.nombre: St. Vincent Martyr of Abando Church
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The present church was built in the 16th century but there was another church before. 

The works were made in masonry and checker work. The church is divided in three naves, five stretches each, separated by classical style columns (with Dorian capitals). The cover is a Gothic style cross ribs vault. 

Two facade doors give access to the inside. The first one is Gothic, with pointed archivolts and jambs. The second one, the main facade, has a lowered and poorly decorated arch supporting a modern belfry by 1894. 

In there we'll find an image of San Vicente Mártir within a niche. The temple has five gold-wood altarpieces, all of them with high-quality sculptures.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Apart from the typical activities of a church, there are several choral concerts all through the year.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Bilbao's urban expansion plan, developed in 1876, foresaw a park in this location but it was not untill 1907 that the works began. Architect Ricardo Bastida and engineer Juan de Eguiraun were responsible for the park's layout. The park is named after local benefactress Casilda Iturrizar.

 

Both designers proposed an eclectic choice of style, combining Romantic and French gardens' styles, and so they mingled straight tree-lined avenues, a circular botanical garden, paths, ponds, and fountains... Other elements were added later: a sports area (basket court...), children's leisure park (swings, carousel...) and a pergola by Juan de Ispizua.

 

The park has become the most important public leisure area in the city.

datosContacto.direccion: Entre el Palacio Euskalduna y el Museo de Bellas Artes

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Campos Eliseos theatre of Bilbao is the best example of Art Nouveau architecture in the Basque Country.

Two architects, Jean Batiste Darroquy and Alfredo Acebal, built it at the beginning of the 20th century.

Jean Batiste Darroquy was responsible, among other things, for the main façade's decoration. A big horseshoe arch welcomes the public. Moreover, the arch presents a rich decoration, with plant, animal and fantasy motifs.

It was originally inaugurated in 1902 and, following almost 20 years of inactivity, it reopened its doors in March 2010, following significant reform. This centre is divided into seven storeys, boasting a surface area of more than 7000 square meters.

The parish church of the Asunción de Santa María of Lekeitio is an excellent example of late Gothic style.

The present temple, finished at the end of the 15th century, replaced an old Romanesque church. Later on, in the 19th century, the church underwent a thorough restoration (paid by Pascual Abaroa) and since then has a new vestry, an ambulatory and a big side portico, all of them in Gothic style.

After the restoration, it was recognised as basilica. The basilica of Santa María is also an interesting architecture and iconography museum. Its is, both from the outside and inside, a spectacular work of art.

Inside, stands out its main altarpiece, a polychromed and gilded Gothic-Flemish piece, recently restored. It is one of the most important in Bizkaia due to its dimensions and polychromy, and even one of the most important in the peninsula. We can also admire its ambulatoryýs highly valuable image collection.

Other remarkable features: the organ and the harmonium, both of Neo-Gothic style. The organ follows the Cavallé-Coll style, and was a donation to the municipality by José Javier de Uribarren in 1854.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: The concerts of the Itxas Soinua International festival are held during the month of August.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Santa Maria de Axpe
datosGenerales.descripcion: This church's construction date is unknown, but the discovery of a medieval necropolis suggests there must have been a temple on this location from the very beginning of the Middle Ages. In fact, some people relate this temple to the church of Santa María de Izpea, which the Counts of Bizkaia -Don Iñigo López and his wife doña Toda- donated to the bishop of Alava in 1051. What seems evident is that the present church's recontruction took place in the 16th century. It has a square plan, one nave and an apse. Its roof covering is a cross ribbed vault with straight ribs. Two altarpieces stand out among the decorative elements: one behind the high altar, of Neoclassical style, and the other one in the chapel of Nuestra Señora del Rosario, in Baroque style.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Concerts are occassionally arranged.

datosGenerales.descripcion: The building of this house dates back to 1791. Manuel de Chirapozu, born in Busturia but who lived and got rich in Mexico, decided to restore this palace belonging to his family. Neoclassical style prevails, even though there are Baroque traces. Neoclassicism is obvious in the three axes of lintelled openings and the facade's simple treatment. On the contrary, the roof's eave and the Virgin's niche in the facade are Baroque elements. The painter José María de Ucelay lived in this house. It is a private residence, that is the reason why visits are not allowed to the interior.

Even though the exact date of the building's construction is unknown, we are certain that there used to be a mill on this location in the 18th century. Zamakola is both a mill and a "caserio" or typical Basque farm-house; that is, apart from the mill facilities, the house is its owners residence. According to the plaque on its façade, the building underwent deep restoration works in 1874. It has a square plan, three floors and hipped roof. This caserio is built in stone masonry, except for the buiding's corners and openings, in cut stone masonry. The mill can be considered an example of Neo-classical popular architecture.

In 1910, Mrs Flora L. De Heredia was awarded the concession contract to exploit the waters of the River Errotazar, and that is when the hydroelectric power station was built. To this purpose, the water conductions of a nearby former mill were used. 

Years later, in 1937, the property was transferred to the company Hijos de Mendizabal, which used the power produced by the station in their Durango factory. 

Nowadays the power station maintains its original facilities: water collector, water tank, pipes and turbines. The power station is normally closed, but it is possible to arrange guided tours in which visitors are given explanations of how this 20th century small station operated.

datosGenerales.nombre: Agustinos Descalzos Convent (San Agustin Kultur Gunea)
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The convent of the Agustinos Descalzos consisted of the church and a residence. It was built in the 16th century and operated up to the 19th century's "desamortización" (sale and secularization of church owned properties).

 

Later on, it was used as a hospital and old people's home. The church, in Renaissance style, is remarkable because of its rectangular and vertical façade with a semi-circular arched portico.  It has large windows and a carved figure of San Agustín occupies the facade's centre.

 

The building is Baroque. It has an inner courtyard and on its facade, by the access door, stands out a coat of arms in the centre and the large abbatial balcony with its forged parapet.

 

Nowadays, the church building hosts a culture centre and the convent is an old people's home.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: The cultural centre that houses the convent, San Agustin Kultur Gunea, organizes theatre and dance performances, as well as music concerts

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Santa Ana's Arch is the only of the gates in the old city walls of Durango still standing today. It is located in the beautiful stone paved square of Santa Ana.

It was built in 1566, but replaced in 1743 by the Town Council, which decided to change the Renaissance door for a more contemporary one, installing a Baroque door.

It boasts a luxurious design: a two-level Triumph arch with a round arched pass. It was built in cut stone masonry.

Its upper level stands on a little terrace, an attic with the Austrias' royal ligneage coat of arms, and two cylindrical rooms on each side covered by a dome.

Durango's Town Hall was built in the 16th century, but had to be restored as a result of the damages suffered in the 1937 bombings. 

 

It is Classical in style and shows Napolitan influences. The building has a square plan and it is divided into two floors and an attic. The portico is built in cut stone masonry, whereas the rest of the building was constructed in brickwork.

 

The building's most interesting elements are located in the main façade. The ground floor has a marvellous portal with seven round arches. There is a large balcony on the first floor with seven openings-doors. The balcony's central door is outstanding, framed by pilasters and supporting a triangular pediment where the village's coat of arms is placed. The attic has seven windows.

 

Inside the building, the paintings decorating the two upper floors are worth admiring. They represent imaginary architectures, llove affairs, hunting scenes... They are copies of the original Rococo paintings by Ignacio de Zumárraga.

Kurutziaga cross was erected in the 15th century and is unique in its kind due to its characteristics. The symbolism it presents may be related to the heresy spread in Durango at the time.

 

The monument, carved in dark sandstone, is full of images and is four and a half metres high. A serpent with a woman's head winds around the flagpole and, above it, appear the protagonists of the Original Sin: Adam and Eve. The twelve apostles are represented in the capital.

 

The upper body shows the most relevant elements of Kurutziaga cross: on the one side a representation of Paradise, and the Stations of the Cross on the other. And there, above the crucifixion, we find images of the moon and the sun, two angels supporting them while two others crown them.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Pedro de Tabira
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of San Pedro de Tabira was built in the 16th century, over a medieval church. One year later, the small chapel of the Virgen del Rosario was added to the North of this church. It is a square-plan Gothic temple. Its choir is worth mentioning, with two lattice floors of Mudejar appearance in its frontal side. The beam supporting it and its heads catch the visitor's attention because of their abstract and stylised decorations. The church keeps many treasures inside, beautiful sculptures as well as paintings. The high altarpiece is an excellent example of painting on wooden panel, typical of the sober Romanist mannerism.
