It is presided by the figure of San Pedro. Underneath the church, there are two sarcophagi that, as legend has it, belong to the mythical earls of Durango: Sancho Estiguiz and Doña Toda.

galeria.titulo: Church of San Pedro de Tabira

datosGenerales.descripcion: The parish church of San Juan Evangelista is located in Garai upper part, at the rear of the Town Hall. This simple temple, founded in the midst of the 16th century, hides in its interior an uncommon ceiling with vaults and wooden coffering. The temple has one nave only, with chamfered apse, a grand portico, a high choir (supported by a wide arch) and a stone-bell tower. The nave is covered by a complex wooden structure, quite rare in the Basque Country. While the interior plan is a unified space, the cover is divided into three parts: the central part, with coffering structure, and the laterals, which host two chapel niches. The belfry, a Neo-classic tower formed by three bodies and finished in a dome, was added to the church in 1850.

The first records of this church date back to 1539. For centuries this sanctuary has been a non-stop witness to pilgrims going to Santiago de Compostela through the northern way. The hermitage is located in the upper part of the mountain of the same name, on the road that takes to Itziar, to be specific. The surroundings of the hermitage provide beautiful views of the Basque coast and the urban area of Deba. This is an ideal spot for a stroll and enjoy the views. Not that long, religious celebrations were held in the surroundings of the hermitage on San Juan and Santa Catalina days. Nowadays only a mass is celebrated on San Juan day (June 24th).

The Lazarraga Palace was built in the second half of the 16th century. It is a square-based building, constructed with different kinds of stone. The roof has four parts and is covered with ceramic-style tiles. The main façade, located in the Eastern part, is divided into two parts. In the ground floor, the door is surrounded by Jonic-style columns and, in the upper floor, there is a coat of arms with classical elements. On both sides of the main entrance door, there are two balconies flanked by stone cantilevers and banisters. Nowadays, in this building is located the Ethnographic Museum of Zalduondo, where lots of customs and the history of the inhabitants of these lands can be learned. There are rooms for Basque ceramics, local craftwork, sacred art, prehistory....in addition, there is an exhibition of the wall paintings and the works awarded by the Premios Zalduendo de Pintura (Zalduendo Painting Awards). At present, this building hosts the Ethnographic Museum of Zalduondo and is the headquarters of the Cultural Association of Zalduondo that manages it.

According to the investigations carried out about Negorta Tower, it is believed that it was constructed at the end of the 15th century or the beginning of the 16th century, probably by a Biscayan noble family. Even today it shows many of the characteristics of a defensive building. It is a three-storey, square-based high tower crowned with a four-side wooden roof. It also has some small openings in the walls. The main façade, facing east, consists of a door framed by an arch and two square windows with a lintel. Regards decoration, it should be noted that there are several emblems of several religious orders and ornaments. It is believed that the tower was originally surrounded by a moat and the access to the inteior could be gained through a door on the first floor and a platform.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Occasional exhibitions, civil weddings, business meetings, conferences, and so on.

datosGenerales.descripcion: Garai Goitia palace, in the urban centre of Garai, is a large country house with a noble and monumental appearance. This ostentatious house, rebuilt in 1754 by Juan and Lope de Garai, is placed over an old and humbler building and its existence has been always linked with Berriz, birthplace of its promoters. The façade is its most valuable element because it presents the main features of Basque country houses complemented with the classic decoration of Italian Renaissance palaces. While the façade is symmetric and carved in sandstone masonry, the ground floor¿s central space stands out because of its wide arch. Over the façade door there are two windows framed in fluted pilasters, and everything is crowned by a beautiful inscription ordered by the Garai family.

The origin of the Santa Cruz hermitage located near the old part's ancient fountain is unknown, even if archaeological remains found in the place make us think that it is very old. In the 19th Century Debaýs Town Council wanted to knock down the temple because they thought that it was very small, deteriorated and located in a profane spot where festivals were held. Luckily, the Bishopric did not accept the suggestion. Tradition has it that this hermitage was worshipping place for those working in the sea: fishermen and seamen and iron carriers that took iron up the river towards different ironworks.

datosGenerales.nombre: The parish church of San Sebastián de Soreasu
datosGenerales.descripcion: In the middle of the old part of town we find the medieval parish church of San Sebastián de Soreasu. The sanctuary dates back to the age of the Templars -the tower is original from that period- but from the 16th century onwards it has been restored on several occasions. The main façade, for instance, is built in Palteresque style and was built in the 18th century following Ventura Rodríguez's design. In the interior it should be noted that the Baroque altarpiece is remarkable, as well as the baptismal font where Saint Ignatius of Loiola was christened. Likewise, the Capilla de la Soledad chapel is worth mentioning too, which hosts a Crib every Christmas since 1894.

The church of Santa Maria was built on a big rock and remains solemn in the village's old part.

 

It was built in 1462 in Gothic style, and restored in the 18th and 19th centuries. The temple has flamboyant tracery windows, and also outstanding are the pinnacles and the rose window. On the river bank, if we look up we will be able to appreciate the large arches under the church, used in the past to protect boats. Its most curious elements are located over the church, the so called "Kortxeleko mamuak".

 

They are Burgundy-style statues that represent a medieval court. Beside them the visitor will find "Leokadi". Legend has it that this woman lived in the old part of the town and turned into stone as a punishment. During the saint patron's festivities, the fiestas of the village, she comes down from the church to enjoy the party.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Music concerts are held in the church all the year

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Old Bridge or Zubi Zaharra and the Cofradía Vieja are one of the most charming places in Ondarroa, and are located in the old part of the village.

 

The Old Bridge links the two banks of the river Artibai. In the 16th century there was a wooden bridge, but another bridge was built in 1795, in a Romanesque style. In 1936, during the Civil War, it was seriously damaged and in 1953 the floodings destroyed it almost completely. As a result, today it is very difficult to see the original structure of the old bridge.

 

The Cofradía de Pescadores is located next to the Old Bridge. The architect Pedro Guimon arranged the project in 1920 and, even so, it looks like medieval. Under the Cofradía we can find the market's square.

galeria.titulo: Cofradia de pescadores and Zubi Zaharra
Cofradia de pescadores and Zubi Zaharra

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Loiola family Tower House was the birthplace of Saint Ignatius, founder of the Society of Jesus in 1491.

 

The house falls within the sanctuary's limits and nowadays hosts a little museum showing Saint Ignatius's family's life, relatives of the Oñacino side, and its most famous person, Saint Ignatius.

 

As many other medieval towers, the Loiola one has a square plan, four floors and hipped floor. After Enrique IV's order to distroy the top of all the defensive buildings, Saint Ignatius de Loiola's grandfather ordered the destruction of the upper part and its rebuilding in Mudejar style.

 

That is the reason why the building has two styles: Gothic in the ground part and Mudejar in the upper part.

datosContacto.direccion: Carretera GI-631, entre Azkoitia y Azpeitia (Santuario de Loiola)

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Spiritual retreat, stays for religious groups and special celebrations for pilgrims.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
In the road between Gautegiz-Arteaga and Ereño there are some old quarries that extracted crystallised limestone rock with coral remains. These deposits were found 2,000 years ago and that's when their exploitation began.

 

The extraction carried on all over history, which is why there were excellent masonry workers. In the 20th century Altzarraga (quarry located in Andrabide neighbourhood) extracted the stone mechanically, by means of helicoid thread, in order to get rectangular marble blocks. We'd like to mention that this stone is easily distinguishable in elements of the Basque cultural and historic heritage.

 

Many churches, palaces and buildings of the country host decorative elements made in this precious stone. Even if nowadays it is not exploited any more, this marble is famous all over the world.

The Patrokua palace was a residence of the Barroeta family. In its construction we can see three different stages: in the 18th century, the Barroeta family built the nearest part to the river. The Gaitán de Aiala family, descendant of the former, enlarged the building by extending it towards the park. In 1945, a loggia was constructed where the two buildings meet each other. The palace has a Baroque garden, which today belongs to an education centre of Lea Artibai. There is an sculpture as a tribute to the writer and priest Juan Antonio Moguel. The monument represents some typographic shapes with a sentence of one of the writer's books: "Peru Abarka". In 2006, the palace was declared as Cultural Heritage, a Monument, by the Basque Government.

datosGenerales.nombre: The parish church of Santa María
datosGenerales.descripcion: The parish church of Santa María is one of the most magnificent churches of Gipuzkoa. It is located in the centre of Deba town and is regarded as a national monument and a real masterpiece of the Basque Gothic. Its dimensions and rich decoration make it comparable to a cathedral. The church has two aisles and a nave of the same height, a polychrome portico of delicate work, a cloister the most ancient one in the territory- and several chapels attached to buttresses. The current sanctuary was built over a former construction between the 15th and the 16th centuries. For instance, many of the elements of the old Gothic church were kept, such as the polychrome façade where the life of the Lady Mary is represented. These sculptures were created in 1465 and painted later in 1682. It was thus one of the nicest façades in the region. The private chapels, property of the well-off families of Deba, and the cloister were built in the 16th century. The lastest construction was the sacristy, built in Baroque style.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Apart from mass services, other activities are held in the cloister, such as concerts of the 'Quincena Musical' ('Musical fortnight'), exhibitions and live music from local bands.

galeria.titulo: The parish church of Santa María

datosGenerales.nombre: Chapel of San Miguel de Arretxinaga
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The chapel of San Miguel de Arretxinaga was built in the 18th century as the previous chapel was in ruins. It has a hexagonal floor plan and a six-sided pyramid roof. It is built in uncut stone.

 

The dome has six nerve blocks, joined in the centre with plant decoration. The chapel entrance is a simple jack arch with a small bell tower on top.

 

The three large rocks inside are the main attraction of the chapel. They support each other, creating a small chapel. At the centre stands the figure of Archangel Michael.  The rocks are over 40 million years old. According to popular legend, young men who want to get married within a year must pass three times under the rocks.

galeria.titulo: Interior of the Chapel of San Miguel

datosGenerales.nombre: Church and cementery of Santa María de la Asunción de Xemein
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of Santa María de la Asunción de Xemein dates from the 16th century. It consists of three naves and shows a combination of Gothic and Renaissance elements. This temple, with a rectangular plan and square apse, houses an outstanding Mannerist altarpiece, a magnificent work of art representing Christ's childhood and Passion. The vestry, choir and belfry were added in the 17th century. The cementery, in Neo-classical style, is attached to the church and has a rectangular plan and a cloister.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Music concerts are held in the church.

datosGenerales.nombre: The hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Loinaz
datosGenerales.descripcion:
First record of the sanctuary dates back to 1565. It is a square plan church with hipped roof. It was built mostly in checker work, even if the corners and windows were built in masonry.

 

The portico's wooden structure draws the visitor's attention and so does the coat of arms of Arriaran lordly house. Inside, the roof has a barrel vault built with hoop arches.

galeria.titulo: The hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Loinaz

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Igartzas were one of the most powerful families in Oria Valley. Around their palace at the entrance to Beasain they gathered all kind of services and, thus, completed their power.

 

In the compound, apart from the family's residence, there was a hermitage, an ironworks, a mill, an apple press, a dovecot, the shoemaker's, the blacksmith's houses...

 

The palace is the building prevailing in the compound. It was built in the 16th Century and divided in two parts: the lower one is built in checker work and the upper one has wooden structure.

 

Restoration works have found mysterious elements as a horoscope written in the 15th Century alphabet or a phrase of that period telling everyday life's basic elements.

The beautiful Arteaga castle, located in a privileged spot in the heart of Urdaibai biosphere reserve, forms a spectacular limestone and marble Neo-gothic tower.

Despite the fact that it has maintained its location since the 13th century, its present structure was designed by French architects Couverchef and Ancelet, who built it again by order of French emperor and empress Napoleon III and Eugenia de Montijo.

They ordered the tower's restoration in appreciation of the appointment of their son Eugenio Bonaparte, by the General Assembly of Bizkaia. as honour son of Bizkaia Thus, Gautegiz-Arteaga saw the building of a Neo-medieval palace, an awesome Neo-gothic tower inspired in French gothic architecture. We'd like to mention the Neo-gothic style shown in the blind arches and the geminate openings or, likewise, in the inner decoration.

Nowadays Arteaga castle operates in the hotel and catering business and offers the possibility to lodge in any of its excellent rooms and enjoy an unforgettable gastronomic evening in an environment that maintains elegantly its original characteristics.

At the beginning of the 16th century, the Franciscan Order of the Regular Observance tried to establish a convent beside the Itziar Sanctuary, but the church chapters opposed and they had to give up. 

 

It was then when Juan Pérez de Licona donated the Sasiola shipyard to the order together with the lands surrounding it, with the aim of building the second Franciscan convent in Gipuzkoa. 

 

There are remaining parts of the ancient cloister, the hospital and the church. The latter has one-nave with belfry and is divided into three parts with special reinforcements in the exterior by means of buttresses and even an arc-boutant. 

 

Inside, there is a magnificent wooden altarpiece dating from the 17th century perfectly preserved that portrays the life of San Francisco.

Muñatones Castle was the culmination of a long construction process lasting from the 14th to the 15th centuries, amid the ferocious factional wars that ravaged Enkarterri. It is without a doubt one of the finest examples of the region’s architectural heritage and has been designated a landmark.

 

Mighty nobleman Don Lope García de Salazar was born in the castle, where he wrote the first history book on the Biscayan people, a first-hand testimony to the blessings and curses of life.

datosPatrimonioCultural.horario: From 15 June to 15 September: Sundays at 10:30 and 12:30.

datosGenerales.nombre: Basilica of Santa María de Uribarri
datosGenerales.descripcion: The basilica of Santa María de Uribarri was built in the 16th Century, attached to Arandoño tower, which nowadays is the belfry. The temple was restored in the 17th century. It is located in the old part and does not have a defined style, due to its building stages: the first one Gothic-Renaissance, dating back to 1500, and the other Classicist-Baroque, of the 17th century. The basilica has a spectacular wooden portico, the biggest in Euskadi. With wooden roof structure, eleven pillars, nine pilasters and the temple¿s walls support the portico. The choir dates back to the first building stage, it has a curious roof full of stars, with images of the moon and the sun. The high altar hosts a Renaissance altarpiece, with a Gothic image of the Virgin of Uribarri, Durango's patron saint.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Music concerts at Christmas or in special days.

galeria.titulo: Basilica of Santa María de Uribarri
Basilica of Santa María de Uribarri

datosGenerales.descripcion: This luxurious Baroque palace was built by José Agustín de Etxezarreta around 1760. It has a square plan that becomes a cubic volume covered by a hipped roof. The main façade holds all the interesting elements. It is organised in five axes of symmetric openings separated from one another by projected mouldings. Over the main entrance there is a sundial. On the third floor there is a wrought iron balcony, with two doors and united to a big corbel from where acanthus leaves hang down. The façade has two pillars on every side, which perforate the roof and become pinnacles. The family's big coat of arms is located among the third and fourth floor, in the centre of the main façade. Nowadays, the Etxezarreta palace hosts Durango's Museo de Arte e Historia museum.

The church of Santa Ana is located in the old part of Durango, in the beautiful stone square bearing the same name and next to Santa Ana's arch. The temple dates back to the 15th century, was enlarged in 1540 and rebuilt again in the 18th century.

 

It is a Baroque temple, simple and sober. Its plan is of Herrera style and includes three naves and a cross ribbed vault. Attached to the body of the church is the belfry, added in 1745.

Sasiola Tower was built in the Middle Ages as a residence and fortress and still maintains some of its defensive features.

 

It is a rectangular-shaped building whose main façade is built completely in masonry. Likewise, it maintains some of the original pointed windows as well as some stone reinforcements where in past times a wooden corbel on the last floor of the tower rested against it and worked as a defensive element, which today does not exist.

 

In the 20th century the building was restored and converted into private dwellings.

The San Andrés church, located on a mountainside in the town of Ibarrangelu, was built in the 16th century in order to replace another medieval church. The current building has a single nave and its high choir was built with Renaissance ashlar walls. In addition, the exterior of the church boasts a stunning tower, which is topped by a sculpture of the Sacred Heart of Jesus. However, the most striking feature of the San Andrés de Ibarrangelua church is its beautiful groined vault, made from wood, in the interior of the church; it is widely accepted that the church's polychrome coffered ceiling is one of the most unique in the Iberian peninsula. It is also worth noting that the church's most complex artwork can be found on the three vaults which cover the chancel.

Gautegiz-Arteaga keeps the only flour tide mill, quite common in the past: the Ozollo Errota tide mill. Likewise, the one in Arteaga is the best kept and the only one keeping almost all its facilities. The mill was built around 1638 near the Laida beach, in the Kanala area. A marshland was closed with walls for the mill and its feedback came from the rear millpond. Apart from the grinding building, where the motor wheels were placed, the mill has another building in the depotýs lowest point. It is a house located on the Riverýs shore, over the water lockgates. Ozollo Errota tide mill is the most valuable heritage element in Urdaibai. The mill stopped its activity at the beginning of the 20th century and nowadays it is a private property.

The hermitage of San Roque is located in the upper part of the village, by the ancient road that goes up to Itziar.

 

The first record on this sanctuary dates back to the early 17th century and as for architecture, its wooden façade door and the choir placed above the hall are worth to mention. The hermitage is setting for some celebrations.

 

In fact, San Roque patron saint festival takes place there on August 16th.

 

On this day this sanctuary opens for mass service and the "eskudantza" dance is performed in several spots along the way from the village to the hermitage by 10 or 12 dancers carrying sticks with red and white laces. On the third Sunday in May, on the Debarra's Day, the "eskudantza" is also danced following mass.

datosGenerales.nombre: Basilica of San Martín of Loinaz
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The basilica was built in the 19th century, ordered by Gipuzkoa's General Assembly, in order to venerate martyr San Martín de Loinaz, born near this place in Amunabarro farmhouse.

 

However, after the Carlist War I the sanctuary was completely destroyed and rebuilt. It was erected in Neo-classical style, with Greek cross plan and square outer plan. It has a complex cover with different slopes and the main façade includes Gipuzkoa's coat of arms.

 

Inside we will find altarpieces consecrated to San Martín de Loinaz and his two martyr companions.

galeria.titulo: Basilica of San Martín of Loinaz

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Palacio Udetxea, located in the historic town centre near the Casa de Juntas and the Tree of Gernika, was built in 1890 by the Allende Salazar family.

 

It was the summer residence of Manuel de Allendesalazar y Muñoz de Salazar, an important figure in the political history of Spain, the Basque Country and Gernika.

 

A visitor to the house during his brief stays in Gernika-Lumo was Miguel de Unamuno y Jugo who, married to Concepción Lizarraga Ecenarro of Gernika, would not miss the chance to visit Manuel Allendesalazar.

 

The building became the property of the Basque government in 1992. Today it houses the offices of the public health department.

datosGenerales.nombre: The parish church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción (Beasain)
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción is located in the upper part of the town. The first record of this temple dates back to 1495. Its construction went through several stages, and because of that we can see different styles, ranging from the late Gothic to the Baroque, as well as the Renaissance. The temple has one single nave and an octagonal apse. Eleven buttresses support the walls that are made up of masonry, although the corners are made up of ashlar. The porch is L-shaped. Accessing the inside is made through a round arch. The whole ceiling consists of ribbed vaults except the apse, which is a plain vault. The parish church is home to a font from which Saint Martín de Loinaz took water in 1566.

galeria.titulo: The parish church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción
The parish church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción
The parish church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción

datosGenerales.descripcion: Manuel Plácido Berriozabalbeitia, who wanted to give a present to his birthplace neighbourhood, ordered the construction of the Berriozabaleta fountain. The money for the mountain came from that earned by him in Peru. The monument is impressive if seen from the road leading to it: on each side of the road there are little pillars every five metres. The fountain and the washing place form the monument, located in the middle of a semi-circular terrace with awesome views towards the Urkiola mountains. The fountain's unique decoration, with categorical, simple and harmonious volumes, is limited to flat panels and a lion head-shaped pipe. On every side there are two small thermal fountains accessed through three stairs. The semi-circular washing place is behind. All that surrounded by a semi-circular wall hosting seven benches. The monument resembles a theatre used as the neighbourhood's meeting point.

The construction of the basilica of la Purísima Concepción began in 1459, in Gothic style, but the works delayed for so long that it evolved into Renaissance style, being finished in 1506.

 

The access doors, rose windows and some columns supporting the portico are samples of Gothic style, and we can appreciate its Renaissance elements in the upper part of the church, in its windows and magnificent bellfry. The church's plant comprises three naves, a very wide central one and notably narrower aisles.

 

Four large columns with Corinthian capitals hold the Gothic cross ribbed vault, and their peculiarity is that vegetal motifs have been replaced by figures representing heads, which are almost grotesque.

 

The choir occupies the width of the three naves. Inside the church, we can also appreciate highly valuable altarpieces, specially the main one and the two on its sides, magnificent examples of Barroque art in the Rococo phase.

 

In the centre of the altar, in a silver shrine, rest the remains of Saint Valentin de Berrio-Otxoa.

Astra-Unceta y cía factory is located in Gernika's La Vega neighbourhood. Built by the architect Ricardo de Bastida y Bilbao, the Unceta company y cía specialised in the so-called Campogiro gun.

 

The building has a deco appearance, and presents elements of Cubism, Constructivism and Italian Futurism. Its activity finished in 1997, the factory was abandoned and it could only be visited from outside.

 

Nowadays, after the factory was auctioned by the Regional Council of Bizkaia, the Astra industrial premises passed on to the Gernika-Lumo Town Council, and the old industrial premises often host several socio-cultural activities. Type of monument: Factory. Car park: Several car parks in the surroundings.

galeria.titulo: Fábrica de Astra-Unceta y cía, Gernika-Lumo

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Agustín de Etxebarria
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of San Agustín is located in the neighbourhood of the same name, a few kilometres from Elorrio. Built at the beginning of the 11th century, and rebuilt again in the 15th century. The present church is of Basque Gothic style. It has one nave only, with ogival ribbed vaults. Inside, the magnificent Plateresque altarpiece stands out, with the image of San Agustin in the middle. The mummified bodies of the Counts of Tabira, founders of the church, rest in stone tombs. A portico surrounds the church, with an 18th century Baroque belfry.

galeria.titulo: Church of San Agustín de Etxebarria

datosGenerales.descripcion: Arezpakotxaga-Mendibil palace is an extraordinary building, one of the noblest and oldest in Elorrio. One of the first buildings built in Baroque style, with sober decoration, it acted as a model for the other palaces in the area. It is a cubic-shaped building with two floors plus an attic. Walls are in brown cut stone masonry, except the ground floor and the western façade, in plain masonry. The coat of arms prevails in the building, divided between the main façade and the eastern one, a location chosen so that it could be seen from any side as one approaches the building from the main square. To the West, stands out a spectacular gallery with four semi-circular arches on Tuscan style columns. Also remarkable is the small tower attached to the eastern façade, a remain of the old walls that used to enclose the village. Type: Palace. Style: Baroque. Period: 17th century. Guided visits: Guided visits must be prearranged with the local Tourist Office by calling a fornight in advance. Tariff: Groups of up to 20 people: 25 euros. Groups up to 40 people: 50 euros. Groups over 40 people: 100 euros. Contact person: Sonia Suberbiola (Urkiola Durangaldea Tourist Consortium) Car park: There is a free car park near the old part of the village. Note: The palace is a private property and its interior cannot be visited. Guided visits around Elorrio include the palace.

Tola palace is a great Baroque building, cubic-shaped and with three floors. It is surrounded by a beautiful garden, in Baroque style too. The palace's most characteristic features are its cylindrical rooms found in its corners, which go over the roof and finish in pinnacles. Its decoration is quite sober and the masonry bond becomes very relevant. The main façade's noble floor has three balconies and the family's coat of arms is placed over the main one. The façade facing South presents a precious balcony leaning to the West. The top floor shows a magnificent gallery formed by three semi-circular arches over Tuscan-style columns. Private palace, access is denied. The exterior of the palace is one of the sites included in the guided tours around the village organized by the local Tourist office.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Concerts in the summertime.

datosGenerales.descripcion: Bergara is a medieval village that has preserved its oldest and most valuable monuments. In the old part we will have the chance to gaze at several Renaissance buildings such as Agirrebeña and Arrese houses, with their corner balconies; even older houses such as the Gothic house where writer Koldo Eleizalde was born (Goenkale no. 3). It should be noted that the Bergara Tourist Information Centre opens in summer, at Easter and bank holidays in autumn. They arrange guided tours around the whole old part of town.

The church of Santa María is located in the urban centre of Gernika, near the Assembly House. This religious building, built in the 15th century, stands out because it merges Gothic and Renaissance styles.

 

This beautiful carved stone and masonry work temple has three naves finished in apses and Gothic cross ribbed vaults. It stands on its eight elegant and classical columns in Ionic style.

 

It possesses an excellent Walckler organ dating back to 1889 and a beautiful belfry by Manuel Capelastegui.

The Agirre palace, known also as Casa Valmar house, is one of the best examples of the civil architecture in Gipuzkoa. It was built in the 15th century, outside the village and next to the river. Surrounded by gardens, it is a strong construction divided in a ground floor and three more storeys. The main façade was built in masonry and has wide windows. All of them are finished with a carved-wood eave. The interior is exquisitely decorated. The main room, for instance, has an awesome decoration in the floor, the walls and the roof. The furniture (lamps, wooden chest, pictures, tables, mirrors, candelabra) are also showy. This property houses the Music School, the Gure-Kai dance group, the Aitzuri choir and band, as well as various other municipal departments and conference rooms.

This lordly house, built in the 17th century over a medieval tower, has a square plan and a hipped roof. Its main façade was built in masonry and brick and has four balconies and the Bikuña family's coat of arms.

 

Another wall consist of a big wooden gallery and the rest was built in masonry and brick. The Bikuña family was a very powerful lineage in the area. They owned several iron works located on the riverbanks of the River Urola and took part in the battle of Navas de Tolosa (1212) and Baeza (1227), as can be seen in its coat of arms.

 

Nowadays, the Bikuña palace is the headquarters of the Fundación Lenbur foundation, responsible for the valley's tourist development and promotion of natural and cultural heritage, as well as the economical and social Development of Urola-Garaia.

Located in the centre of Gernika-Lumo, Alegría palace hosts the Museo Euskal Herria, or museum of the Basque Country. This magnificent Baroque palace, built in 1773, stands out because of its cut stone masonry façade, railed balconies and the coat of arms of the Allende Salazar family. It is also closely linked to the history of the Basque Country and explains the origins and the development of the country by means of engravings, models and an excellent cartography. Besides, the restored palace is surrounded by beautiful gardens, one of them in French and Romantic style and the other in English style.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Juan de Molinar
datosGenerales.descripcion: The Church of San Juan de Molinar is a remarkable monument of Biscay. It was built in the 16th century in Baroque style. The elements added subsequently are of Renaissance style. The choir and the belfry, for instance, are Classical (17th century). The temple has one nave only, covered by complex vaults. Inside, the high altarpiece stands out, a Baroque masterpiece including several images of angels, San Juan Evangelista and a Gothic image of Nuestra Señora de Isasi.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: At Christmas and other times of the year, concerts are held in the church.

galeria.titulo: Church of San Juan de Molinar

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Oxirando complex comprises the palace and the tower, and has been declared as a Monument in Bizkaia. The tower of late Gothic-style (late 15th century) has a square base and is divided in three storeys. 

The main entrance is under a round arch. The first floor was devoted to daily life activities and has special medieval windows. The last storey used to be a wide, more illuminated lounge. In the main facade we can see the coat of arms of the Palacio family. On the other hand, the Renaissance-style (16th century) palace is terraced, linked to the tower in its western part. Both have the same height and are built with masonry. 

The entrance is a great masterpiece but the most relevant is is the 'loggia' located in the last storey, a decorated cornice separates it from the storey below, and a balcony over which there are Tuscan columns united by archs.

datosPatrimonioCultural.estiloArtistico: The tower has a late Gothic style and the palace is Renaissance-style.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Located in Lezo's Plaza del Santo Cristo Square, in the beginning the basilica of Santo Cristo was a hermitage. Inside, the visitor could gaze at a Christ carving dating back to the 10th century, a beardless Christ made in Byzantine style.

 

This image, still kept in the sanctuary, has great artistic value according to experts, many legends revolve around it, thereby attracting many visitors every year. In fact, from the end of the 16th century on, devotion spread and the present Renaissance basilica was built where the ancient hermitage took place. Another peculiar feature of the church is the existence of objects donated by devotees as a sign of gratitude or request.

 

Several boat models offered by seamen hang down from the sanctuary's roof. What is more, there is a beautiful altarpiece from the 18th century within the basilica of Santo Cristo.

 

Although there are no guided tours around the sanctuary, there is a Cicerone Spot in Plaza del Santo Cristo Square. Information and auto-guide service by mobile phone enables getting to know better Oarsoaldea's tourist places. As to Lezo, they also provide information on the basilica of Santo Cristo.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Concerts take place in the sanctuary sporadically as the acoustics are very good.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
In this town, birthplace of the Idiazabal cheese, there is a sculpture, a tribute, to the Basque shepherd.

 

They, shepherds, have managed that this cheese, made up of 'latxa' sheep raw cheese, has become the most special product of the Basque cuisine. Shepherding is, moreover, one of the hardest jobs, since shepherds spend most of the time in cabins scattered around Aizkorri and Aralar. This monument was built in honour of all those people who live shepherding. It was sculpted with great care.

 

The shepherd, in one of the typical Basque costumes, holds a lamb in his arms, while a shepherd dog looks at him on the right.

Segura was an important town in the Middle Ages.

Its location, beside the road which connected Gipuzkoa with Castile, meant that many people, including merchants, knights and pilgrims, passed through the town. 

Today, Segura's is one of the best preserved medieval quarters in Gipuzkoa, boasting a notable Historic-Artistic Heritage which includes numerous buildings, ancestral houses and palaces, as well as two of the gateways in the old town walls. 

The Town Hall sits in the old Lardizabal Palace, which was built in the 17th century. The impressive Lardizabal family coat of arms stands out. The Arrue Ancestral House, which includes a display of Mudéjar art on one of its facades, represents one of the few examples of this style in Gipuzkoa. The Guevara Ancestral House, meanwhile, built in the Late Middle Ages, has managed to preserve its voussoired door, on top of which sit three small coats of arms. Segura used to be a walled town, and some of the gateways which once granted access to its interior are still intact today.

These gateways currently mark out the old town area. Segura¿s most striking religious monument is the Nuestra Señora de la Asunción church, with its Baroque-Rococo altarpiece. It was erected in the 16th century.

datosGenerales.nombre: The church of San Juan Bautista (Arrasate-Mondragón)
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of San Juan Bautista was built in the 13th-14th centuries and is located in front of the Town Hall. The building has Latin cross plan, one nave, two aisles and an apse. Its high walls and ogival arches show that those who ordered the construction opted for Gothic style. Likewise, this sanctuary consists of quite peculiar elements in Basque religious architecture: gargoyles. This animal faces have two functions: expelling the roof's water and decorating. It was said also that they scared the parishioners and thus they embraced more vigorously their faith in God. The belfry was built and attached to the church in the 16th century and the parish church was restored in the 1990s. Alto Deba Tourist Information Centre organises guided tours to the Old Part, which also tours this church.

Horcasitas Palace is located in the town centre of Balmaseda.

 

Its construction was ordered by Lucas de Horcasitas, in 1686. Of Neoclassical style, it has some Baroque elements. The palace is a four-storey building and surrounded by a garden and a fence. As for its original layout, its lower floors housed the winery and the stables, whereas the rooms and lounges were located on the upper floors. The attic was on the last floor. Built in ashlar, the main facade has balconies of forged steel, surrounded by the coat of arms of the Horcasitas family.

 

The main entrance is located between two Corinthian-style columns that, at the same time, support the main balcony.

datosGenerales.nombre: Hermitage of San Miguel de Ereñozar
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The hermitage of San Miguel de Ereñozar can be seen from every corner in Gernika's Ria. It is located over Ereño Mountain, just above Santimamiñe caves.

 

Built in the 10th Century, the hermitage has rectangular plan, with checker work walls and masonry in the corners. With a gable roof, the hermitage has a wide portico. In its southern part the mountain refuge is attached to it.

 

Beside the entrance we can find an outer trapezoidal shape monolithic sepulchre with inner anthropomorphic hollow. The legend has it that it is not the only sepulchre near the hermitage.

 

Due to its excellent location, the hermitage offers an awesome view of Urdaibai.

 

How to get:

We take the regional road BI-638 Gernika-Lekeitio and once we are in Ereño we take a paved local road, just behind the Town Hall, that leads us through the north-east side of Ereñozar mountain, untill we reach the base of the summit. Then we can park the car at a small area and we must go walking along the final stretch by a small steep and rocky path, surrounded by a small forest of strawberry trees.

galeria.titulo: Hermitage of San Miguel de Ereñozar
Hermitage of San Miguel de Ereñozar

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Ybargoen tower was built in the 16th century (there is nothing left of the former tower). One century later, it was renovated and a new storey and new windows were added. Recently, the new owners have done more restorations.

 

Due to this, the whole structure of the tower has been transformed. The building is cubic and has four floors. The ground floor was used as a stable and the first floor as a residence, which was accessible by means of an outdoor stone staircase, which today no longer exists. The entrance is located under a round arch. Because the fist storey is very high, another storey and more windows were made, and the building was thus composed by four storeys. The attic looks onto the outside part in order for the products to be exposed to the open air and keep fresh; instead of windows, battlements were used for this.

 

Type of monument: Tower. Period: 16th century.

Access requirements: Private property.

Distance to the town centre: 1 km.

Parking: Parking is allowed nearby.

Aiete Palace was built in 1878 by the Duke and Duchess of Bailén. Pilgrims on the Way of St. James pass the building on their journey. This neo-classical building is attributed to French architect Adolfo Ombrecht, and is one of the most valuable buildings in San Sebastián.

 

It embodies, as does the city as a whole, the fine tastes from the end of the 19th century. Until Miramar Palace was built in 1893, it was once the residence of Spanish monarchs Isabel II, Alfonso XII, María Cristina and Alfonso XIII. Many illustrious people have passed through its rooms, such as Queen Elizabeth of England and Empress Eugénie de Montijo. San Sebastián was also a summer holiday resort during the Franco years. Between 1941 and 1975, General Francisco Franco chose the palace as his summer residence. The dictator set off from here to his famous meeting with Adolf Hitler in Hendaya and it was in the palace's suites that he took the decision to become an ally to the Americans.

 

Renovated in 2010, today it houses the House of Peace and Human Rights. It also boasts the Aiete Cultural Park: in addition to the 3,660 square metres occupied by the House of Peace and the Aiete Cultural Centre, it contains gardens and esplanades, a park for children, a Bonsai pavilion, a bar and restaurant, etc. The Park stands out for its plants, trees and gardens which, stretching over 74,000 square metres, were designed by the royal gardener Ducasse, who learnt his craft as a garden architect in Versailles.

The nice church of Santiago Apóstol was built in the 16th Century, enlarged and built again in 1602. In Renaissance style, its belfry maintains a formal dialogue with that in Valdespina palace, just opposite to it. The belfry is Baroque, with an octagonal bell room, and it is finished with a dome and a pinnacle. The church has only one nave with side chapels. The high altarpiece is a spectacular work in walnut tree without polychrome with Solomonic columns full of decoration. It has Polychrome sculptures, the one of Santiago prevailing among them.

The Cuba villa was built in 1885, but at the beginning of the 20th century its new owner redecorated it in a Neobaroque style.

 

The building is a square-base complex. In the main facade there is a porch of Renaissance-style, full of adornments and Tuscan columns. The most important elements are located in that facade: windows and Neobaroque balconies, for instance.

 

The Cuba villa has a nice garden, with a rooftop garden and a cave dedicated to the Lady of Lourdes.

Valdespina Palace was built in the late 18th century. It is a big building and its dome, majestic, is overlooked by the church of Santiago's belfry. The dome is semi-circular, with a lantern crowned with a pinnacle, ball and weathercock. There is a chamfered tambour below. The main facade, the one facing the church, is the most attractive one since it contains more elements of interest. The main entrance is placed in the central axe and there are two more axes to the sides. The palace consists of three floors, the two upper ones with five balconies. As the visitor walks upstairs, the balconies' decoration becomes more complex. The third floor balconies have classic pediments. Likewise, it is worth mentioning that the coat of arms belongs to Orbe and Larreátegui lineages. They are decorated with dead leaves. Nowadays this Baroque building hosts the Ermua Town Council.

datosGenerales.nombre: Hermitage of San Cristóbal de Elgezua
datosGenerales.descripcion: The medieval hermitage of San Cristóbal de Elgezua, located in Igorre's Santa Lucía neighbourhood, forms a very interesting artistic-archaeological site. The building has rectangular plan and was built in late Romanesque style. The interior shows a 16th century Neo-gothic altarpiece with an image of Nuestra Señora de la Ascensión and polychrome wooden carvings of Santa Lucía and San Cristóbal, dating back to the 18th century. The hermitage presents a wooden choir and it is surrounded by a beautiful landscape.

galeria.titulo: Hermitage of San Cristóbal de Elgezua

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Gipuzkoa square, located in the city centre of San Sebastián, is one of the most emblematic places in the city. It is noteworthy the presence of the sculpture of pianist and composer José María Usandizaga, as well as a small meteorologycal pergola, a large clock-table made of white marmol and a large clock made of flowers of different colours.

 

Its gardens and paths, which are located in the middle of the square are meeting and resting spots for many citizens of which many grew up feeding the pond's ducks. In front of the square we will find the headquarters of the regional council of Gipuzkoa, which was built back in 1885 by architect José de Goicoa.

 

The impressive Neoclassic building's entablatures bear the busts of popular sailors from Gipuzkoa.

 

What is more, throughout the year the square plays host to several activities, such as the book fair and the children's funfairs in the summertime. It is also worth visiting the Crib installed there at Christmas times.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Santa María de Idibalzaga
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of Santa María de Idibalzaga displays two different styles: Renaissance and Neoclassical. Some of the walls and the facade door date back to the 16th century, whereas the interior is the fruit of a restoration carried out in the 19th century. The church has rectangular plan, saloon plan without apse. Its length is twice as long as its width and it is divided into five-stretch three naves. Two rows of Tuscan style four classic columns support the dome. The facade door is a great example of mannerism, built in 1560, under a semi-circular arch framed in pilasters and with medallions of Saint Peter and Saint Paul. Its interior hosts the "Gorputz Santue" (Saint Body), an incorrupt and miracle-worker kept in a niche in its own chapel, very popular in Bizkaia.

galeria.titulo: Church of Santa María de Idibalzaga

datosGenerales.nombre: Memorial to José María Martínez de las Rivas
datosGenerales.descripcion: The sculpture is a memorial to the businessman José María Martínez de la Rivas, a key figure in Bizkaia's industrialisation process developed at the end of the 18th century and early 19th century. This bronze monument is formed by a statue over a pedestal. The cubic-shaped plinth is decorated with images recalling scenes that the guest of honour experienced: mining exploitation, shipping companies and house building. Below the statue there are four human beings -a woman, a man and two children- depicting the inhabitants in a thankful attitude towards the businessman, making a flower offering. This is one of the main tribute monuments in Bizkaia, mainly due to its historical value.

The Urrutia house is a marvellous colonial-style building. It was built in the 20th century as a summer residence of the Urrutia family. 

The French influence can be seen in several elements: the lateral platforms that become terraces on the second floor, the three-arch galleries of the main façade, the three-dimensional composition or the imperial staircase. Modernism is expressed, for instance, in the balconies' iron fittings and the cresting. 

It consists of a four-storey building: the basement and three floors, the first one as public area and the other two for private use. The interior was decorated following Spanish Neo-Renaissance style: panelled walls, the dining-room door and glazed doors. 

The Urrutia villa is surrounded by an English-style garden with a rooftop garden, the gardener's house and a pond. 

Nowadays, it is Güeñes Town Hall.

The La Quadra tower is in the Cadagua valley. The tower, which belonged to the Quadra family, was built in the 15th century and played an important role in the local fights during the Middle Ages. It is a more complicated tower than it may be thought.

 

It is almost 20 metres high and has an inner wall. The base is square and the walls are built with masonry and ashlar. The tower has three floors; the ground floor was used as a stable, store and, when necessary, as a prison. On the first floor, eight-metre high, was the main residence and the upper floor had one room only, illuminated by pointed windows. A ogee window stands out, with the coats of arms of the Salcedo and Zamudio families.

 

The inner structure was made in wood and the roof is pyramidal. Type of monument: Tower. Period: 15th century. Distance to the town centre: 5 km. Car park: Near the tower there is a parking place. Observations: The tower is a private property.

datosContacto.direccion: Barrio de La Quadra de Arriba

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The hermitage of Gurutzeta is the former parish church of Idiazabal. The altarpiece is made of golden wood and contains a Gothic carving of the Virgin of Kurutzeta dating back to the end of the 13th century.

 

It has been restored several times and can be found nowadays lying on a silver throne from Granada's R. Moreno workshop. The hermitage has rectangular plan, wooden ceiling and a baptismal font dating from the 16th century, which occupies the place of a previous one dating back to the 8th century.

 

What is more, it has mementos related to Brother Sebastián Elorza, an Augustinian born in 1882 who lived in Arizkorreta-Saletxe farmhouse, very close to the hermitage. In past times crowds of people attended the place to seek for somewhere to shelter during journeys. It was restored in 1972.

The Sanctuary of Angosto is located outside the municipality of Villanañe. This basílica was founded to honour the Virgin of the same name. 

Legend has it that, in 1089, a shepherd found an image of the Virgin floating on the waters after a flood, and that is where the name of Angosto comes from. There is a cave dedicated to the Virgin in the place where the image was found. The church is Gothic in style and has a simple structure. It was erected in the first half of the 14th century. Inside, visitors can admire a beautiful altarpiece consisting of 6 panels that tell the story of the Virgin, whose image presides the altarpiece, a carving from the 14th century belonging to the group called "Andre-Mari". 

Next to the Sanctuary is the Escuela de Espiritualidad (Spirituality school), a place to recover one's strength and gain insight into one's faith in silence and peace. It also houses a youth and pilgrims hostel. The Sanctuary of Angosto is close to Valderejo Natural Park. 

Type: Sanctuary. Style: Gothic.

Period: Middle Ages (14th century). 

Contact person: Padre Jesús.

Activities: In July, there is a festivity gathering all the municipalities with parish churches under the authority of the Angosto Sanctuary. 

Car park: There is a public car park next to the Sanctuary. 

Note: There is a camping nearby.

galeria.titulo: Cave of the Virgen de Angosto

datosGenerales.nombre: The church of San Miguel Archangel
datosGenerales.descripcion: Located in the centre of Idiazabal, the church of San Miguel Archangel is situated in one of the most emblematic buildings in town. The Romanesque-Gothic front door was built between the 12th and 13th centuries and side engravings and geometrical signs carved in it reveal its age. Inside, beautiful groined vaults from the 17th century crown the place and the baptismal font was transferred from the hermitage of Kurutzeta. Another gem hidden in the interior is the fantastic Baroque altarpiece designed by Miguel Irazusta and built by José Antonio Iparragirre. Juan Bautista Mendizabal carried out most of the sculptures in it and the retable was rounded off in the 18th century.

galeria.titulo: The church of San Miguel Archangel

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Ertzilla raised granary of Iurreta was built in the 16th Century, as in past times these structures were very common in the farmhouses of the Eastern Valleys of Bizkaia, mainly in the Duranguesado region. Built in oak wood and raised upon four sandstorm pilasters. The woods fit perfectly well without metal nails. These granaries were raised in order to protect them against animals and humidity. Apart from storing wheat, fruit and meat... they represented also the family's social prestige.

 

A stone staircase leads to the granary. The last step is gone in order to prevent animals from entering the granary. A small balcony divides every section, each of them with its own door and lock. The granary has gable roof.

 

In the 19th Century the granary was not used any more and was abandoned. It was built again in 1987, giving it its original appearance.

The church of Santa María was built in the 16th century. The temple merges Gothic (façade door and the first stretch) and Renaissance elements (rest of the church). It has three naves divided in four stretches, and the arches of the four-pointed stellar vaults rest on columns. The southern façade door is spectacular and richly decorated. It merges Gothic and Renaissance styles. The rear façade is a triumphal arch between pilasters. The high altarpiece, in polychromed wood, is one of the most notable pieces from the 17th century Baroque, the period's Classicist and severe phase. The church of Santa María hosts many other treasures inside: furniture, paintings and craftsmanship in precious metals, for instance.

The hermitage of Santa Elena, also known as Ama Xantalen, is located near the old part of the town of Irun, by the bank of the River Estebenea. It is an important hermitage for it has been a place of cult for many centuries. The current building was probably erected during the 14th century and has a rectangular plan, hipped roof cover and cut stone walls. The portal of the hermitage is of Isabelline style. During the 1970's, several excavations were carried out in this hermitage and an incineration necropolis of Roman morphology was found, as well as the remains of a Roman temple that existed before the 1st century. Converted into a museum, Santa Elena displays the remains found on the place -coins, utensils, ceramics..- as well as many others from different archaeological sites of the Bidasoa region that are records of the presence of a Roman period settlement known as Oiasso.

This magnificent tower-house was ordered in 1605 by Cristóbal de Ipeñarrieta. It is a rectangular-based building in whose central part there is another rectangular construction. The main façade and the second construction are build in sandstone-ashlar, and the rest in masonry. The main façade shows two family coat of arms in Carrara marble, with this motto: "Soli deo honor et gloria" (To God, only honour and glory). In the 16th and 17th centuries this palace was magnificent, and many of the Ipeñarrieta were important in the Spanish court. Likewise, the king Phillip III stayed in this house when he went to Bidasoa to give his two daughters for marriage. From the 18th centuries, the Izagirre family has lived in this house, which has been used for farming activities. Type of monument: Palace. Period: 17th century. Observations: The building is a private house, not open for tourists. Visits: Lenbur, the agency for the tourism development of the region, offers didactic visits to this country house where the traditional farming activities are shown. Parking: The Santa Barbara neighbourhood has plenty of parking spaces.

The church of San Miguel of Iurreta was built in the 19th century, beside the old Rococo tower. Built in Neo-classical style, the plan is a Greek cross over a square framed within a larger rectangle. The apse has a semi-circular open space and there is a high choir at the opposite end. Inside, there is a modern altarpiece with the image of San Miguel Archangel.

 

The portico faces South and is formed by semi-circular arches with a little pediment in the middle.

 

The tower was built in 1788 in cut sandstone masonry, and consists of three sections divided by mouldings. A lantern and a small dome with a weather vane cover it.

datosGenerales.nombre: The church of San Miguel Arcángel
datosGenerales.descripcion: The peculiar church of San Miguel de Arcángel is located in Aldaba neighbourhood, Tolosa (Gipuzkoa), 12 kilometres from the town centre. It is a little chuch, which was a hermitage till 1881. In 1962 it was completely restored and a lot of work was done. The altarpiece is worth mentioning because it is an enormous display window that allows admiring the beautiful Sierra de Aralar. This church was done by Pérez San Román.

galeria.titulo: The church of San Miguel Arcángel

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Martin de Tours
datosGenerales.descripcion: The San Martín de Tours church, located at Plaza Iparragirre, is of medieval origin, most likely dating back to the time when the town was founded. However, the church¿s appearance today owes largely to the renovations that have been carried out on it from the 16th century onwards. For example, the apse had to be knocked down in 1861 in order to make way for the Azkoitia road. Its austere and solid construction suggests that it originally also served a defensive function. With a sober façade, its interior is a harmonious blend of gothic, Renaissance and even Baroque designs. The precious wooden dome which covers the temple is particularly striking, and is a gem of the wooden architecture that was so popular in this town.

galeria.titulo: Church of San Martin de Tours
Church of San Martin de Tours / photo: urretxu.eus

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Berriatua Tower, also known as Sulengua -meaning "prior to fire"- is one of the few buildings surviving to the violent fire that destroyed Mutriku in 1543.

 

It is believed that the building is the oldest building in town and is considered to be the highest medieval tower-house in Gipuzkoa. It functioned as a watchtower in past times in the port. It is a big tower built in sandstorm masonry with Gothic and Renaissance elements. The building has geminate and ogee windows and, besides, pointed arches. On the other hand, there is an entrance with an interesting geometric decoration.

 

Nowadays it is a private building.

Muxika tower house, built in the 10th Century by the owners of the Arteaga house, was the scene for many side wars. The present building is a large-size work built over a prior wall and rests over a hillock that oversees a beautiful landscape.

 

Moreover, it mixes the architectural styles typical of tower houses and rural palaces because its interior was occupied by a renaissance palace, but with some Gothic elements too. The building's main structure, formed by a patio and a residence, was restored in the 19th Century, and so it was the cover, changed partially.

 

Type: Tower. Period: 14th Century. Access requirement: It is a private building so visits are not allowed to the interior. Urban centre: 4 km.

The Galdona Palace is located in the middle of the town's old quarter, by the church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción and opposite the Town Hall. The structure was built at the end of the 17th century. It has a quadrangular plan built in masonry except the main façade, which is constructed in ashlar. What is more, it is a three-storey structure with a hipped roof and paying attention to one of the corners on the first floor we will find an interesting quartered coat of arms. Next to the main building there is a small one dating back to the 17th century, which is the current tourist office. At the entrance you will find the Arraturriaga fountain.

datosGenerales.nombre: The church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción (Mutriku)
datosGenerales.descripcion: The Nuestra Señora de la Asunción church is located in the centre of Mutriku. It has been declared a National Monument of the Basque Autonomous Community, and provides one of the best examples of Gipuzkoa's neoclassical architecture. The building was designed by the Madrid-born architect Silvestre Pérez, but the project was carried forward by Manuel Vicente Laca and Mariano José Lascurain, both of whom were architects from the San Fernando academy and Mutriku natives. The temple has a Greek-cross plan and its exterior was constructed with Ashlar stone, while the interior alternates between walls of exposed masonry and Ashlar columns and arches. The façade of the portico is made up of six Doric columns, upon which the architrave sits. In the interior of the church, in the left chapel, there is a beautiful canvas depicting the figure of Christ on the cross. It was painted by Francisco de Zurbarán.

The Montalivet Palace is a lordly building that draws the visitor's attention due to its segmented arch. Architect Francisco Ibero built it in the 18th century by orders of Lord Oña where another house was erected before. It is a three-storey building with three-sided roof, square plan and constructed over a very uneven land. The main façade is built in ashlar. In its lower part there is a semi basement, whereas on the left side, among pilasters, there is a stilted arch functioning as an access that also includes an embrasure above. A wrap around balcony occupies the main façade and the coat of arms, located in a corner between the left and the main facades, are some of the most appealing features of the building.

Lucas de Olazaharra captain ordered the construction of this house in the end of the 17th century. Its main façade is built in masonry and the structure consists of ground floor and three floors. On the ground floor, the access has a moulding around the door and windows at the sides with bars. As for the first floor, four openings join in pairs to form a wrought iron balcony that contains a great coat of arms in the middle. A wide and long balcony on the second floor also covers the four windows and bears in the middle an artisan painting fanned out. To finish, the third floor has also four openings, two side and two central spaces joined by a balcony of the same structure. To round it off, it should be mentioned that a wide eave with drawings engraved in the beams are similar to Galdona Palace's. Nowadays the building houses private dwellings.

The Town Hall is one of the most emblematic buildings in Mutriku.

 

Located in the Plaza Churruca square, it was built in 1731. The three-storey large building has square plan and a hipped-roof. It consists of a central construction and two side bodies. Besides, it is built in masonry and has a traditional portico and an entrance porch. Moreover, it has a wrap around balcony and three coats of arms decorate the building's façade.

 

The tourist office organises guided tours around the old town where information on the Town Hall is provided. Tours for 4-50 people.

The Zabiel Palace was erected in 16th and the main facade was built in cut sandstone masonry. The building is a three-storey structure whose middle floor is the most appealing of the three due to the architectural decoration. On the second floor we will have the chance to gaze at helical shaft columns with beautiful Ionic capitals. Besides, the building has an exquisite coat of arms above a small pelota court and the palace is crowned by a protruding eave. The Zabiel Palace has kept some of its ancient elements. For instance, the left bottom of the facade is a lancet arch with seven voussoirs forming an access. At the back facade a path leads to a narrow street where it is possible to see the trace remains of a machicolation of cut sandstone. In past times it functioned as a school. Nowadays, following restoration works, it operates as the Mutriku cultural centre.

datosGenerales.nombre: Hermitage of San Miguel de Zumetzaga
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The hermitage of San Miguel de Zumetxaga is located in Mungia, at the feet of mount Jata. It is the best-known building of Basque late Romanesque style in Bizkaia.

 

The building has one rectangular nave built in checker work and presided over by a portico at the front entrance.

 

The apse's window is outstanding. Likewise, the outer columns are worth mentioning too, with circular elements, rhombus' nets and string baskets.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Each September 29th a mass is celebrated to honour San Miguel

galeria.titulo: Hermitage of San Miguel de Zumetzaga

datosGenerales.nombre: John Palace (La Bolsa or Stock Market Building)
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Palacio John, also known as the Edificio de la Bolsa (old Stock Market Building), is located in Bilbao's old part. This Baroque building opens to three different streets. 

The most spectacular façade faces onto calle Pelota Street. The main entrance has a lintol surounded by mouldings mixing straight and curved lines. This façade includes a vaulted niche with the image of the Virgen de Begoña. 

The entrance in calle Torre Street is more austere, with a balcony above. This façade bears the coat of arms belonging to four Byscaine families. 

The palace was built in cut-stone masonry and has an inner courtyard. It consists of three floors linked by a stone staircase. 

Nowadays the Edificio de La Bolsa is a cultural and social centre. Type: Palace. Style: Baroque. Activities: Talks, lectures, press conferences and different events. It is a cultural centre. Car park: Pay car parks nearby.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Talks, lectures, press conferences and various other activities are organised. The building is a cultural centre.

datosGenerales.descripcion: La Colina palace dates back to the 18th Century. This Baroque building has a vegetable garden that reaches the river. It is cubic shaped with a hipped roof and it was built in checker work. It is divided in three plants, the first two as a residence and the cabin used as storeroom for vegetables. In the main façade (left) there are two arches that give access to the inner part. Over the right arch there is a balcony and, even higher, the visitor will admire the coat of arms. Type: Palace. Style: Baroque. Car park: There is a parking area nearby.

Those houses are known as casas de labranza (farm houses), where farmers used to live. Their architecture is not very common in Bizkaia's houses. They have wooden balconies upon the street that protect the grass and carriages from rain. Most times houses consisted of a ground floor and the first floor. Some of them held a second floor that was used as an attic. Nowadays, as they have lost their function as farmhouses, many of them have been restored.

This monument was built in memory of Juan Sebastián Elcano, one of the most distinguished important figures in Getaria.

 

The sculpture displays elements of the Art Deco style, which was in vogue during the period in which it was built. It sits on an old bastion of the wall of Getaria, which serves as its base. The monument is crowned with a Winged Victory of Samothrace, in the style of the figureheads which adorned the prow of the vessels. On the lower section, a bas-relief by the same sculptor portrays Juan Sebastián Elcano; inside the building, an inscription lists the names of the other crew members who, together with Elcano, successfully completed the voyage.

 

It should be mentioned that there are two statues of Elcano in town: one in Plaza Elcano dating back to 1861 and built by Antonio Palao and Plaza de los Gudaris built in 1888 by Ricardo Bellver.

galeria.titulo: Elcano, statue in front of the town hall

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Biañez old church was built between the 15th-16th centuries.

 

There is no vault on its nave but it has a Gothic pointed façade door with austere decoration. A marvellous treasure of the church's apse was discovered thanks to some restoration works. When workers took off the Baroque altarpiece dating back to the 17th Century, they found some Renaissance murals. They looked like an altarpiece's structure and depicted Christ´s Passion. They form 90 square metres of paintings and date back to 1535-1540.

 

They were restored in 1993.

This beautiful bridge is the first of four located in the estuary of the River Urumea in San Sebastián. Built to connect the neighbourhood of Gros, La Zurriola Bridge, also known as Kursaal Bridge, was built in 1915, although its structure was modified due to the continuous battering of the waves.

 

The bridge consists of four spaces spanning three central supports, and two side supports. 

 

Its futuristic and expressionist streetlights complete this glamorous pass located between Kursaal Palace, with its two turrets designed by Rafael Moneo that evoke stranded rocks, and the Victoria Eugenia Theatre, home to important events on the cultural life in Donostia-San Sebastián.

Hernáiz brothers ordered the construction of the house in 1904 when they came back from Puerto Rico as rich men. They entrusted it to French-Basque architect Jean Batiste Darriquy.

 

His participation was decisive for the building's final appearance because he merged several styles: Neo-Norman for complex coverings, eclecticism in mouldings for hollows and corners and modernism for the façade door and the ground floor's terrace.

 

But its uneven structure and the colour variety (red wood, limestone-gray, slate black and cream paint) were the most outstanding features of Hernáiz house.

 

The house was restored in 1971 and divided in three residences, thus changing its interior. Private property closed to the public.

Sagastigutia park is situated in the urban centre of town, a few metres away from the parish church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción. It is ideal for a relaxing stroll in natural landscapes, despite being located in the urban centre. 

The park is full of over 50 tree species such as holly, oak and chestnut trees. Likewise, it offers the chance to walk along different paths that lead to an area with tables, barbecues and fountains. It is the perfect spot to enjoy in the open air. 

In the upper part of the park we will have the chance to ganze at the beautiful views of the Goierri region.

Juan Ramón Arana built the majestic Arana palace in 1852 and it is located in Izurtza. Neoclassic building with outstanding residence dimensions, it is divided in three floors, all of them very distinguishable. The garden is also worth admiring, a beautiful woods with a marvellous pond. The compound has been always admired because of its beauty and nowadays it is a private property. Type: Palace. Style: Neoclassic. Period: 19th Century. Access requirements: The palace is a private property so only the outside can be visited.

When he came back from Cuba at the beginning of the 20th Century, where he made his fortune, Luís Portillo bought a country house, restored it and turned it into a summer residence. Architect Jean Batiste Darroquy was responsible for the project. 

 

The building's report was not easy because, taking the old building as a base, he had to build a new one. He had to turn a country house into a middle class building, one with the entrance facing southwards into another whose entrance would face westwards. The architect respected the old building but east and west façades, where he added new bodies. 

 

Portillo presents a mixture of styles: Eclectic classicism and Neo-Basque styles in the new bodies and wooden structure in the old parts. Red and cream prevail in the building. The roof is very complex too, with wide projections and many slopes.

On the road between Durango-Urkiola, in the municipality of Izurtza, the visitor will find the Etxaburu tower, one of the most popular in Bizkaia. It is an outstanding tower, placed over a high rock, thus offering a magnificent view of the surrounding area.

 

The tower has rectangular plan and Sancho López de Ibargoen and his wife Estíbaliz de Etxaburu built it in the 16th Century. Strengthened by square checker work walls, Etxaburu tower has a wide arch creating a tunnel under the building.

 

Type: Tower. Period: 16th Century. Access requirement: Visits to the interior not allowed.

The church of San Martin is located in Getaria, in the Askizu neighbourhood. As well as being one of Gipuzkoa's Gothic jewels, this building preserves some features which are considered to be the first examples of this style in the province. It has only one nave, a wide portico and two sections of vaults with intermediate ribs. In terms of material, walls and vaults are built in sandstone ashlar work. Archaeological excavations in the Early Middle Age cemetery of San Martin in 2007 unveiled anthropomorphic graves carved in rocks which are unique in Gipuzkoa.

The church of San Miguel Arcangel of Oñati is the best example of a building that has been constructed throughout several centuries, thus adding elements of different styles.

 

The original church, built in the 13th century, had one nave only. Both lateral aisles were added two centuries later by means of flying buttresses. The cloister was built in the 16th century -Gothic-blazing style- and so were the pulpit and chapel, both in Renaissance style. The crypt dates back to the 17th century and, finally, the works finished one hundred years later with the main façade, two Baroque altarpieces and the Neoclassical tower.

 

Apart from the extraordinarily beautiful altarpieces, mausoleums and tombs in its interior are worth to mention. The tomb belonging to Archbishop Rodrigo Mercado de Zuazola, for instance, depicts images of the Passion and the Virgin's, saints' and prophets' life.

datosGenerales.nombre: Hermitage of San Pedro de Elorriaga
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The hermitage of San Pedro de Elorriaga, located in Lemoa, was rebuilt in 1910. With rectangular shape, the building has one nave only and nine steles that form the biggest group of Roman epigraphs in Bizkaia.

 

However, this beautiful temple's main characteristics is that connects three different stele groups; indigenous, Greco-Roman iconography and, finally, steles that localise both iconographies adding Latin texts and Roman decorations. Moreover, those steles dating back to the Roman period are the most relevant ones found in Bizkaia.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: It celebrates the day of San Pedro

galeria.titulo: Hermitage of San Pedro de Elorriaga

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Juan López de Lazarraga, accountant of the Catholic King and Queen, and his wife Juana de Ganboa wanted the right place for their tombs so they ordered to construct this monastery in the beginning of the 16th century.

 

The building displays three different artistic styles as follows: Gothic, Mudejar and Renaissance, the latter being the prevailing one. Likewise, the two altarpieces are worth to mention. One of them, depicting the Virgin's coronation, is Baroque and built in non-polychromatic wood. The other is Plateresque, one of the first Renaissance altarpieces in the territory.

 

Cloistered Franciscan nuns of the Order of Saint Claire inhabit the convent.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Bartolome de Aldeacueva
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The church of San Bartolome de Aldeacueva is a building of large dimensions built in the 18th century.

 

The temple merges Baroque and Neo-classical styles and its plan is a Greek cross framed within a rectangle. At the rear there is a choir. The church has two types of vault: a blind dome in the transcept crossing and barrels in the rest. Columns faced by Tuscan pillars support the building. In the main façade, the entrance is placed under a semi-circular arch supported by great pilasters. The door has a flat tympanum with a pediment over it.

 

This façade has a tower on each side, which end in a pinnacle.

galeria.titulo: Church of San Bartolome de Aldeacueva

datosGenerales.descripcion: After Oñati's incorporation to Gipuzkoa, a plan was arranged to organise its urban structure. This square, which hosts the Town Hall, was included in the plan. In order to carry out the project, architects Mariano José de Lascurain and Antonio Cortazar covered the river and channels merging at this point. Two buildings were erected with arcades. Following the Neoclassical style, a pelota court was included in the square and the perspective was left open facing south. Near the square the visitor will find Lazarraga Palace, which was originally Gothic but was restored and extended throughout the 15th and 16th centuries.

When regent Queen María Cristina, King Alfonso XIII's mother, began spending her summer holidays in Donostia-San Sebastián, arose the need of building a "Royal Country House". The Queen chose the Count of Morianna's property, a small hillock between the city centre and Antiguo neighbourhood, with fantastic views of La Concha bay.

 

Following the project by English architect Selden Wornum, master builder José Goikoa built the structure in English style, but added some Neo-Gothic elements too. 

The compound was completed with stables, workshop and coach houses. Besides, they built a big park designed by Pierre Ducasse. In all, Miramar Palace and the park cover a surface area of 34,136 square metres.

 

After the Queen's decease the property went to Alfonso XIII. During the II Republic it was expropriated and, years later, given back to the Borbón family. The Town Council bought a part of the propriety (present palace and gardens) in 1972.

 

Nowadays the gardens are open to the public but normally the building is closed. The building hosts, for instance, summer courses by the University of the Basque Country and some concerts from the Musical Fortnight.

The Memorial to the Basque Shepherd by Néstor Basterretxea (Bermeo, 1924), one of the best Basque sculptors of the 20th century, is, as the name points out, a homage to Basque shepherds. The piece of steel was inaugurated on September 20th of 1998. The sculpture bears a plaque with an inscription that says:"Euskal Herriak euskal artzainari" (The Basque people to the Basque shepherd).
