Garibai Tower, of which many documents give testimony of its existence in the 14th century, is located on the outskirts of Oñati, by the river in Torreauzo neighbourhood.

 

It makes up an interesting complex together with two houses of Lazarraga lineage and the hermitage of San Pedro. The main building has rectangular plan and crowned with a hipped roof with a pinnacle of Herreran style - Spanish architecture style from the period of the Renaissance- in every vertex. It consists of a basement, first floor and an attic.

 

The tower was the dwelling of the feudal men of Garibai. Nowadays, the building is a private residence, so visits are not allowed.

Olakua tower-house, built in the 15th and 16th centuries, is located 200 metres away from the Monastery of Bidaurreta.

 

The structure, of medieval style, has an entrance in the shape of ogival arches. Over the past years it operated as a farmhouse and mill, until the Monastery of Bidaurreta was finished, where the Poor Clare Sisters took shelter.

 

Completely restored, it nowadays hosts municipal offices.

Santa Catalina Bridge is the second of the four bridges across the River Urumea in Donostia-San Sebastián and links up two main roads of the city, Avenida de la Libertad Avenue and Calle de Miracruz Street. 

 

The first records on the bridge date back to the 14th century. The ancient wooden pass was the only one connecting both banks until the 19th century, for they knocked down the old wooden pass in 1870 and built the present one in Neoclassic style under the supervision of Antonio Cortázar. 

 

The bridge consists of four depressed arches and masonry with light coloured stone from Mutriku and red limestone from Ereño.

datosContacto.direccion: Entre el Paseo de Francia y el Paseo de los Fueros

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Miguel de Ahedo
datosGenerales.descripcion:
San Miguel of Ahedo was built in the 17th century on the remains of an earlier church.

 

A pitched-roof building with a nave but no side aisles, it displays a mixture of Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque features. The main facade culminates in a bell-gable with small semicircular arches from which the bells hang.

 

The main altarpiece in the church is Gothic, from 1640, and is renowned as one of the most interesting altarpieces from that period. Inside, a Romanesque triangular piece with bas-reliefs from the original 12th-century church is now on display following the general restoration works conducted in 2001.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Apart of the religious services, during the whole year they organise music concerts.

galeria.titulo: Church of San Miguel de Ahedo

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The church of Santa Cecilia was built between 17th and 18th centuries in Classicist Baroque style.

 

Built in checker work and masonry. The temple is divided in two square stretches and an apse with the same width. The first stretch has two chapels, San Juan Bautista and Rosario chapels. The church has a Gothic cross ribs. The temple's entrance is located in a façade crowned by a belfry. The door is located under a semi-circular triumphal arch placed between pilasters. Above it, in a niche, we can see the image of Santa Cecilia.

 

The church presents magnificent altarpieces and the high one, in polychrome wood, is Baroque.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Santo Tomás de Olabarrieta
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of Santo Tomás de Olabarrieta is located in an oak tree wood in Zeberio. It is a wide and significant Gothic building dating back to the 15th century. Its spectacular arcade and its amazing pavement shine in his own right. Formed by a rectangular three-stretch plan, the church of Santo Tomás de Olabarrieta has star-shaped vaults and Renaissance choir. The vestry is interesting too and operates as a parish museum, the best one in Biscay.

galeria.titulo: Church of Santo Tomás de Olabarrieta

datosGenerales.nombre: Portalondo House or Tower of the Gentiles
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Portalondo House or Tower of the Gentiles is a building of rectangular floor plan and a three-slope roof. It forms a party wall on its right side and its rear façade is occupied by a town house, whereas the other two facades are free. It finishes the medieval subdivision of a block in Kardaberaz street in its meeting with Perkaiztegi street.

 

It is a medieval tower-house, pollarded in the second half of the 15th century, which possibly formed part of the defensive wall of the town and was sited next to one of the gates thereof.

 

Its outside is made with ashlar stone. It has four geminate windows of a pointed arch with a mullion on the first floor.

 

Meanwhile, in its facade giving on to Perkaiztegi street, there stands out a triangular based addition made up of three floors.

 

On the ground floor it presents major construction and compositional changes due to the anarchic opening of holes in business premises. The holes in the top floor are also of a rear opening.

 

Currently, there is a business premise on the ground floor and residential properties on the other two floors.

datosPatrimonioCultural.periodo: Medieval Age. The upper structure of the tower-house was removed in the second half of the 15th century.

datosGenerales.nombre: The church of San Juan Bautista (Hernani)
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The church of San Juan Bautista is located in the centre of Hernani town, in plaza Gudarien enparantza Square.

 

In the past, Hernani's church was located in the current convent of the Agustinas but was transferred to the centre in order to contribute to the village's development.

 

The building has one nave only, with Latin cross plan. Inside, we will see the high altarpiece's tabernacle by Ambrosio de Bengoechea.

datosGenerales.nombre: Hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Zeberiogana
datosGenerales.descripcion: The hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Zeberiogana is one of the best architectural elements in Zeberio. The building, with rectangular plan is divided in four parts, all of them covered with edges except the second, bigger than the rest and covered with a vault. On the other hand, in the hermitage we will find three Rococo altarpieces, made by Domingo Gutiérrez and polychromed by Luis de Foncueba. The main feature of Zeberiogana hermitage is the choir (one of the most important choirs of Bizkaia), artistically very valuable and keeping its original polychrome. The hermitage also keeps interesting vessels.

galeria.titulo: Hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Zeberiogana

datosGenerales.descripcion: Mallabia has one of the most emblematic rural palaces in Bizkaia. The building, merging the elegance of Baroque and Neo-classic styles, was built in the middle of the 18th Century by Juan Bautista de Urizar y Amézaga. Amezaga palace is a robust three-storey cubic-shaped building. Its main characteristic is that it connects two different structures because it has a checker work façade and another much more slender façade formed by five pillars with spectacular galleries.

The lime kiln of San Justo is located in an oak forest next to the hermitage of Justo y Pastor. With a structure of the type known as French, the lime kiln of San Justo is characterized by the fact that it is excavated in an area with a slope.

 

Even though the structure had been abandoned since 1950, the association Ipizki Taldea started recovery efforts of the lime kiln in 1996. Since then, this association puts the lime kiln in operation every August. The structure can be visited from the outside.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: On the first Sunday in August there is an exhibit in the hermitage that is situated next to the limestone quarry

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The church of San Francisco is located in the centre of Tolosa, beside the triangle square. The building has a basilica plan and an altarpiece in the high altar.

 

  Likewise, it is worth mentioning the coat of arms of the Antia lineage found on one of the church's laterals, the emblem of one of the most important families in Tolosa.

The square was built between the 18th and 19th centuries as a result of the Bourgeois and erudite spirit prevailing in the village's gentry. An example would be the magnificent castles such as the Baroque Antia and Madinabeitia; Moyua House, which is tipical of the 19th century and nowaday's cultural house, and the beautiful Baruekua Palace, going through a period of transition from Baroque to Neoclassical. It belonged to Lord Areizaga, earl of Peñaflorida's father-in-law. It is worth mentioning the gardens and fountains.

Bishop Rodrigo Mercado de Zuazola was totally convinced that Basque people had a special ability for arts and established a University in his hometown, Oñati.

The institution operated from 1542 to 1901 and taught Theology, Canons, Law and Medicine.

A main courtyard, chapel, classrooms, kitchen and dining room on the ground floor and bedrooms and the main lounge on the first floor formed the Oñati University.

The main façade is the most valuable feature of the building. It is divided into five parts separated by pilasters and decorated by sculptor Piarres Picart. The façade door's iconography shows Christian and pagan values to the students.

Nowadays the building hosts the Basque Institute of Public Administration, Gipuzkoa's Historic Archives and Oñati's National Institute of Law Sociology.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Santa María de la Asunción (Mañaria)
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of Santa María or Nuestra Señora de la Asunción is one of the best and most valuables in the region. It is a large building with one nave, chamfered apse and perimeter portico, built in the 16th Century. Likewise, we'd like to emphasise the wooden cross ribs vault that maintains its Renaissance character. Besides, this beautiful church hosts five altarpieces and an organ. The high altarpiece forms an important Baroque structure in polychrome wood.

datosGenerales.nombre: Parish church of San Esteban de Lartaun
datosGenerales.descripcion: The parish church of San Esteban was constructed with just one nave and cross ribbed vaults. The temple had to be rebuilt as a consequence of the fire that broke out in 1476, and the works continued during the following centuries. The tower with only a few windows gives way to a fortress-looking structure that was designed by Nicolás de Lizarraga together with large buttresses. Inside, among the elements worth mentioning is the altarpiece, a piece by Juan de Huici dating back to the 17th century and declared Cultural Asset by the Basque Government.

Santiago Arechaga ordered Arechaga house but the present building was entrusted to architect Alfredo Acebal in 1910. For that purpose, Acebal designed an English-style building and received the National Architecture Award.

 

Ubide building stands out because of its English influence, evident in the whole structure. However, its eclectic style can be seen also in the access staircase and the main façade's entrance.

 

As it is a private property, visits to the interior are not allowed.

The Saint Mary's church, with a surface of 1630 square meters, is located in the historic quarter of Tolosa, in the Santa Maria square, next to the town hall. It has a hall with three naves of great height. Likewise, false ribbed vaults can be seen, all of them supported by six large columns. The front of the baptistry dates from the 13th century and it belonged to Saint Stephen's chapel. It was moved to this church in 1918. As far as the inside is concerned, we can admire a central altarpiece, as well as several images painted on the side walls. These alterations of a neoclassic nature were introduced at the beginning of the 19th century by the architect Silvestre Pérez.

The palacio de la Puente palace is the municipality's most outstanding architectural structure. The palace, with square plan and hipped roof, has three floors. The building¿s main façade presents sandstorm masonry and the coat of arms of La Puente family. The palace is a private property so visits to the interior are not allowed.

Artzu is located in an exceptional landscape between the foothills of Mount Jaizkibel and the Cantabrian sea, 20 km from Donostia-San Sebastián.

 

It operates as a farmhouse and consists of six rooms. Besides, guests will have the opportunity to gaze at the coats of arms and the certifying parchments that give account of the stories and heroic deeds which took place in this place.

 

Hondarribia Tourist Office has arranged a wide range of activities that are included in the programme. Activities are as follows: horse riding, hiking routes, sailing, fishing, canoeing, paragliding, touristic cycling, trips by all-terrain vehicles, guided cultural routes, swimming and trips to caves and beaches.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: horse riding, hiking routes, sailing, fishing, canoeing, paragliding, touristic cycling, trips by all-terrain vehicles, guided cultural routes, swimming and trips to caves and beaches.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The hermitage of San Esteban is located in the boundary of Oñati on the way to Arantzazu in Lezesarri neighbourhood. Almost in front of the Memorial to the Basque Shepherd by Nestor Basterretxea.

 

Documents show that the church was built in 1505, but visitors can appreciate important reforms dating back to the 16th and 19th centuries. The structure consists of a wide wooden covering and an ogival portal.

 

A crucifix prevails in the altar, on whose sides the images of San Crispín and San Crispiano marching in Corpus Christi procession and San Esteban's were placed. Moreover, one of the walls still keeps a copy of a bull dating back to 1738. The bull was granted in 1620 to San Crispín and San Crispiano brotherhood.

Cristóbal de Ipeñarrieta ordered this building's construction in the 17th century. It is a pink-colour limestone building and its main façade presents two coats of arms of the Ipeñarrieta lineage in white marble.

 

The two upper floors have two rows of balconies in wrought iron. In 1892, it was bought by the Town Council in order to serve as Town Hall premises, which explains why its interior has been thoroughly refurbished. It is believed that painter Velázquez lodged here during one of his stays in the Basque Country.

 

The truth is that Velázquez met Mrs. Antonia de Ipeñarrieta when she was lady-in-waiting of Queen Isabel de Borbón and he painted her portrait, which can be nowadays admired in Madrid's Museo del Prado. Urretxu's Town Hall, however, displays a copy of this painting in its art gallery, which includes other portraits and paintings linked to the village (Jose Maria Iparragirre, Gaspar de Jauregi, Tomás de Ipeñarrieta and Idiaquez and el Cardenal Necolalde).

The church of San Pedro Romaña is a square building with three naves and polygonal apse; moreover, it was embellished with masonry and checker work walls. Another interesting feature of the church: it mixes late Gothic and Classicist style. On the other hand, the church¿s altarpieces form a significant Baroque compound.

Located 2 kilometres from the centre of Oñati town, in Garagaltza neighbourhood to be precise, the hermitage of San Juan Bautista dates back to the 16th century but was restored in the 19th century.

 

It is a wide sanctuary consisting of a rectangular plan and its main feature is the altarpiece, dating from 1613-1622. Near the hermitage, visitors will find the devotional spot of the Ángel de la Guarda (guardian angel), with an 18th-century image.

The small hermitage of San Lorenzo is located on a straight road between Legazpi and Oñati, to the right, by ETEO centre.

 

Although its walls were built in masonry the building features a cyma reversa portal with large voussoirs. Later on, the belfry, vault and choir were added. Documented evidence show the hermitage was built in 1505. A bylaw was made in 1609 to apply to members of the church.

 

Until the 1930s the representative municipal government would march in procession to the hermitage on August 10th, San Lorenzo's Day. Nowadays San Lorenzo's Day is still celebrated by means of a mass service in the hermitage.

The San Martín hermitage, located on a hill and surrounded by the San Martín path and a beautiful oak grove, was built at the beginning of the 16th century. The design is a simple one. Particularly striking are the hermitage's wooden framework and the pointed arch at its entrance.

 

The beautiful central altarpiece is the work of Pierre Picart. Inside, four bas-reliefs depict various scenes from the life of San Martín.

 

The belfry, from the 18th century, and the portico, from the end of the 19th century - or beginning of the 20th century - are also particularly noteworthy.

 

This hermitage was home to various brotherhoods: the Herreros de Oñati, under the patronage of San Martín, and the Hermandad de San Roke. The hermitage's utilities remain in full working order, and a mass is held every year on the feast of San Martín (11th November).

The hermitage of Santa Lucía is located approximately one kilometre from the urban centre of Oñati, in Berazao neighbourhood. Documented evidence reveals that the simple hermitage consisting of an entrance in the shape of an ogival arch and a wide arcade was built in 1567. In the past, three altarpieces adorned the sanctuary. One was devoted to Santa Lucía, another one to San Jorge and the third to Santa Cruz. Following their removal, they constructed a window in the wall with a view of the landscape. The same wall contains an image of Santa Lucía. Previously, Mass was held every Sunday. However, these days Mass is celebrated only on December 13th, Santa Lucía festivity.

Located in the Soraitz district, the Gurrutxaga Goikoa farmhouse is a building with a rectangular plan and gabled roof.

 

At its main façade, there is a portal with two semi-circular arches and, above these in the centre, sits the coat of arms. The building openings are placed symmetrically and framed in stone and wood.

 

On the first floor there are two ledged balconies and a large balcony sits above these.

The hermitage of San Roque, built around 1700 in popular Baroque style, is placed in a nice spot near a bullring. Its rectangular plan and semi-circular apse stand out and its appealing choir is worth mentioning too, and so it is the small vestry. The bullring, on the other hand, was built in 1692 and restored in 1983, when it received its present circular shape and a checker of work barrier. The hermitage is closed normally so no access is allowed to the interior.

The beautiful church of Santa María is located in Plentzia's old part. With a simple structure and masonry walls, the building stands out because of its special cover in wood framework, a project developed by architect Severino de Achúcarro in 1887. Likewise, we would like to mention the excellent series of five alabasters that form a poliptych with scenes of the Way of the Cross.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Music concerts are celebrated the first fortnight of September.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Dotorekua house was founded in the 16th century by Dr. Juan Ortiz de Zarauz, Corregidor of Castro Urdiales. Located in a corner of the old town, it has a rectangular plan and three floors.

 

The entrance is decorated with a large, pointed arch. The façade is particularly striking, as it displays a coat of arms from the Zarauz family lineage. Today, the building belongs to the Laboral Kutxa bank, and it is therefore not possible to take a tour of the interior of the building. However, the firm ARAZI explains the history behind this emblematic building on its guided tours, which offer people the chance to learn about Zarautz's monumental heritage.

 

Guided tours:

  • July and August from tuesday to saturday at 11:30, departures from Zarautz Art and History Museum.

 

Guided tours are available all year round. If you wish to arrange a guided tour, you can ring up on 943 833 641, or alternatively you can send an e-mail to the following address: arazi@arazi.eus

 

For more information, please visit http://www.arazi.eus

La Casa Consistorial de Otxandio, or Otxandio Town Hall, is located in the town's urban nucleus, beside the pelota court and the church, and is one of the most interesting sites in this Bizkaia town. It is a two-storey building with a rectangular plan and a main façade in sandstone masonry.

 

In addition, it is a harmonious building, with perfectly measured dimensions. Similarly, the arched porch and the generously-sized balconies make this Ayuntamiento one of the most spectacular town halls in Bizkaia. In 1733, the Otxandio corporation decided to build a new town hall, after it became apparent that the previous building was no longer big enough for the town's needs. The new town hall was opened on 1st January, 1737.

 

Although most of the history of its construction is unknown, it is known that its coats of arms were the work of the highland sculptor Jerónimo de Liermo and that the carpentry was carried out by Antonio de Isasmendi, an Otxandio resident.

Located in the old town of San Sebastián, the church of San Vicente is thought to be the oldest one in the city. It was built in the early 16th century in Basque Gothic style under the orders of masters of quarry Miguel de Santa Celay and Juan de Urrutia.

 

The building has a rectangular plan and one nave and two aisles. Its rose windows and pointed arches are amazing, and draw the attention of those visiting the old part.

 

The inside is sober but amazing and it confers a sense of calmness. Among its gems we'd like to mention the presbytery's altarpiece, done by the sculptor Ambrosio de Bengoechea.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church, monastery and school of the Franciscans
datosGenerales.descripcion: It is a buildings compound (church, convent and school), that keeps a rich history within its walls. The convent was built in 1610 and was expanded and restored later on. Nowadays the church has a Latin cross plan and three naves covered by groin vaults, but the central one. Inside, the visitor will find a Flemish triptych painted by Antonio Blocklandt in 1577.

galeria.titulo: Iglesia, convento y colegio de los Franciscanos
Iglesia, convento y colegio de los Franciscanos

datosGenerales.nombre: The Castle of Emperor Carlos V
datosGenerales.descripcion:
Located in the plaza de las Armas Square, in the walled old part of Hondarribia, the Castle of Carlos V dates back to the times of the Goths.

 

In the past, this building was both a castle and palace. Thus, it was used to lodge important people and members of the royal family. The building had two lateral naves covered by very high ogival vaults. In 1794, the French army destroyed part of the building.

 

Since 1968 the building operates as a tourist hotel. Beautiful corners and rooms decorated with coffered arches surround the visitor with an atmosphere of indescribable beauty. Spears, cannons and armours are part of the decoration providing the atmosphere with a touch of elegance.

galeria.titulo: The Castle of Emperor Carlos V
The Castle of Emperor Carlos V

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The palace, dating back to the 16th century and built in sandstorm masonry, has square plan. It is a Renaissance style building where the arch-shaped facade door stands out. Likewise, the door is crowned with the house's big coat of arms.

 

Located in the seafront, a beautiful garden surrounds the building.

 

Type: Palace. Style: Renaissance. Period: 16th century. Parking: There are several underground car parks in the city centre, apart from OTA regulated parking areas.

The Portu House, currently the Town Hall, has carried out different functions throughout its long history (post office, telegraph¿). It was erected by the family of the same name in the 16th century, although the facade expresses a later inspiration.

 

Located in the Plaza de los Fueros, it is a palatial building of rectangular floor plan and three heights. The main façade is made from ashlar, of a symmetric composition with three cavities per floor. Access is given by a spacious door framed by classic fluted columns which hold the base of the first floor central balcony. It has two windows at the sides with Baroque motifs on the lintels. The remaining cavities are wrought iron balconies.

 

Two Ionic pilasters emphasize the monumentality of the building. On the 17th of January 1964 it was declared an Artistic Historical Monument.

Built in the 17th century, the Casa Solar or Barrena Palace is one of the most important constructions in the town, as it was the headquarters of the General Council of Gipuzkoa for many years. It is a rectangular building with a ground floor and three storeys.

 

Its three façades are made up of different architectural styles. It was connected via a gallery with a house named Casa de Jaques (currently the headquarters of the Town Council social services) until the gallery was demolished in the Second Carlist War and both buildings were separated. Visitors will note the beautiful main staircase, made of well-carved stone, and the magnificent halls on the first floor.

 

It currently houses the offices of the cultural centre and the music school, and the forest at the foot of its southern façade, designed by Juan de Herrera, director of the work on the El Escorial monastery, has been converted into a public garden.

datosGenerales.nombre: The church of Santa María de la Asunción y del Manzano
datosGenerales.descripcion: It dates back to the 16th century and presents Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque features. The church's plan is Latin cross-shaped and has three uneven naves as well as three polygonal apses leaning on the naves' top. The naves are covered with very varied groin vaults. Particularly notable is the vault leaning on an arch decorated with religious and heraldic icons. Also worth mentioning is the high chapel's altarpiece, built in Neo-Gothic style in 1910. It preserves two images from the original altarpiece and golden colour prevails. The church has two main entrances. The one facing north is the oldest of the two and an elliptic arch assembled in a vaulted atrium shelters the entrance. The decoration includes stone balls and flanked with pinnacles. The other entrance is located in calle Mayor Street. It's a door-level porch covered with a barrel vault.

For centuries, Sagartegieta Palace has been very powerful in this area. Its dwellers (first the Sagartegieta and later the Sustaeta) always ruled the area of Maltzaga, a key point for communications in Gipuzkoa, because this is the place where the roads to Bizkaia and the one from the Gipuzkoa coast to Castile meet. Aparently, the building was quite simple in the beginning. Later, it turned into a palace when its dwellers gained power. It was built in 1655 and restored in the 18th century in Baroque and Neoclassical style. In the 20th century, however, it was abandoned after the Civil War. The coat of arms carved in the porch and reads: "Soy Sagarteguieta. Vinculada en 13 de maio de 1655 y corroborada en 23 de maio de 1765".

datosContacto.descripcionNumeroTelefono: Debegesa, the Development Agency of the Lower Deba

datosGenerales.descripcion: Eibar was established around the Church of San Andrés. The original building was made of wood and the construction of the present church began in the 15th century and nowadays it is the most significant building in town. Its plan is cross-shaped, with one nave and two aisles of the same height and a star-shaped vault. The capitals of the columns supporting the vault are Corinthian, unique of its kind in Gipuzkoa. The belfry and the main façade door, in Baroque style, were the latest elements to be built. However, the northern façade is worth admiring too; it dates back to the 16th century and combines Renaissance and Plateresque styles.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Santa Maria de la Asuncion
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The original church of Santa María was built at the end of the 13th century or early 14th century, but nowadays, there are only remains on the base of the current Baroque tower.

 

The present church, with one nave and apse, dates back to the 16th century. The interior keeps a Gothic image of the Virgin from the 14th century, several chapels and altarpieces. The high altarpiece, by Bartolomé Cordero, dates back to the 17th century.

 

The local Tourist Office organizes guided visits touring all the monuments in the old part of the village, including this church.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Different concerts are held in the church throughout the year.

galeria.titulo: Church of Santa Maria de la Asuncion

datosGenerales.descripcion:
This old Basque farmhouse is located on the slopes of Mount Jaizkibel, close to the sanctuary of Guadalupe.

 

It is a building of large dimensions and a long history behind.

 

It should be noted that in the past, Sancho Abarca King of Navarre dwelt in this house because he fell desperately in love with one of the maids working there.

 

Nowadays it is a private residence and also operates as bar and restaurant, attracting many people not only because of its beautiful natural setting but also to enjoy the food served here.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción (Zumarraga)
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The construction of this temple began in 1576, but it had to be carried out in several stages. At first, most of the temple was erected in Basque Gothic style. It has a hall, three naves of equal height covered by a ribbed vault that supports itself on columns with a cylindrical shaft and on Doric capitals. The main façade, however, is from the Baroque period and it is accessed by means of a wide porch that has round arches.

 

On the vertical plane of the façade rises the tower, which has a square floor plan and a Baroque finish. In terms of interior decoration, noteworthy are a Baroque Christ, the work of Mauricio Valdivielso, and the beautiful main altarpiece, from the 18th century with Baroque and neoclassic elements.

The Sanctuary of Arrate is a landmark for believers in this valley. It is a simple, one-nave Gothic-style temple. Inside, on the contrary, it keeps real masterpieces, such as paintings by Ignacio Zuloaga. 

Nevertheless, the image of Our Lady of Arrate is a key element of worship here. The Lady dates from the 14th century but records from the 13th century mention her. In the oldest documents, she is named as "Arriarteko Andra Mari" (The Lady among the rocks). 

This Lady is very popular not only among believers of this place but also among sailors -there's a replica of a ship hanging from the ceiling- and among the local instrument players -txistu and trikitixa players, to be precise-, who regard her as their patron. The festivity is celebrated on September 8th with a major mass and a procession.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Juan Bautista (Pasai Donibane)
datosGenerales.descripcion: Located in Pasai Donibane, the parish church of San Juan is an outstanding-size construction dating back to the 17th century and built in cut sandstone masonry by Miguel Beldarrain and Simón de Pedrosa. It has a Latin cross plan, a cross-shaped nave and Classical columns at the main door. Its outer appearance is characterised by the sombre Herreran-style façade. Above the post and lintel spanning the door, over two Doric columns, a niche set within a tabernacle framing with a stone image of San Juan Bautista. Crammed into a retaining wall there is a stone head sculpture called "Mascarón de Iriberri" (Iriberri figurehead) by the town inhabitants. Victor Hugo referred to the church as "the mysterious sculpture". Inside, the most significant artistic element is the altarpiece of the high altar, by Sebastián de Lekuona, from Oiartzun. A beautiful image of San Juan Bautista by Donostia-San Sebastián's Felipe Arizmendi also prevails. His are also the sculptures of San Pedro and San Pablo located on the sides of the central sculpture. A wax image of Santa Faustina is a present from cardinal Zurla to D. Juan Manuel Ferrer.

This tower house is known as Casa Legazpi because it was the birthplace of Miguel López de Legazpi, conqueror of the Philippines. It was built by the lord of Balda in the climax of side battles, in the Middle Ages. It presents all the features of defence buildings even if it was dismantled in the 15th century following Castille's King Enrique IV's orders. Its plan is rectangular, with four floors and gable roof. The lower part is built in masonry while the upper one is built in brickwork and keeps visible its wooden structure. The gardens surrounding the building are visible too.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: The building is used for different events such as press conferences, presentations, conferences, civil marriages...

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The popular hermitage of Nuestra Señora de los Remedios de Larraitz is located on the foothills of Mount Txindoki (1,346m), in a privileged spot, for it is situated in one of the main accesses to the Aralar Natural Park.

 

This building dating back to the 17th century is consecrated to the Virgin Mary and venerates her by means of a Gothic carving in which she holds the baby on her left arm. Seamen and farmers in the area worship the Virgin, as they have always believed the scuplture has miracle powers.

 

Moreover, many mountaineers begin Txindoki's ascent from this beautiful spot. Besides, in the surroundings of this hermitage there are several restaurants and a picnic spot with benches and tables that are full of people in summertime and at the weekends.

 

On June 29, Saint Peter's Day, the hermitage holds a large procession in the hermitage.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: The first Sunday of July commemorates San Pedro Festivity.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The city wall enclosing the old part of Hondarribia is one of the clearest testimonies of the village's medieval origin. Its structure underwent many extensions as a consequence of the development of the city.

The thick and high walls built in masonry with limestone from Jaizkibel surrounded the city till the end of the 18th century.

The Santa María turret, the bastion of the Queen, the San Nicolás fortress and the Santiago bastion are structures that have survived until today, we cannot say the same about the Magdalena bastion, whose remains are underground, right under the current city.

datosGenerales.nombre: The church of Nuestra Señora del Juncal
datosGenerales.descripcion: The building was declared Historic Monument in June of 1973. It was erected in the 16th century but but there was controversy. Due to its size and location, Hondarribia and Navarre's Viceroy opposed against its construction arguing that it could help the enemies shelter. However, building works were carried out and in the early 17th century the tower's weather vane was placed following over 100 years of works. Thus, the church combines very ancient Gothic elements and Basque Gothic. The church of Nuestra Señora del Juncal has rectangular plan with one nave, three aisles, a flat-front apse and a tower made of stones from Amasa. The high altarpiece shows a Romanesque image in Bizantium style consecrated to the Virgen del Juncal that dates back to the 12th century, the oldest one known in Gipuzkoa. Outside, we will find the façade, made in masonry, and a Baroque façade door dating back to the 17th century.

galeria.titulo: The church of Nuestra Señora del Juncal
The church of Nuestra Señora del Juncal

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The beautiful Garro Palace was built in the 17th century in Baroque style and is located in the middle of Leintz-Gatzaga. Totally restored, it has been the municipality's cultural centre and toy library since 1987.

The facade is quite appealing for it has a coat of arms with lily flower-cross and four wolves facing each other.

We will find the exhibition room on the first floor, which also houses Toki Eder ¿a recreational and cultural society-, the toy library, the library and meeting rooms. The premises measure 70 square metres that can be divided into two separate halls where groups and associations with no profit motive in mind carry out exhibitions.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: The Town Council and the Cultural Centre arrange several activities.

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The first documents of the hermitage of Santiago date back to the 15th century. However, some of its characteristics seem to suggest that it comes from prior periods as, for instance, a trumpet-shaped Romanesque style. 

Nowadays the building belongs to heirs of paintor Ignacio Zuloaga. It was the artist himself who, at the beginning of the 20th century, restored the hermitage and built next to it a museum and private studio. 

As a consequence, it is the best opportunity to admire Zuloaga's best works and a magnificent private collection formed by works of renowned artists such as El Greco ("El Cristo de la Cruz") and several sculptures by Rodin.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Conferences and similar events

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Terreros tower was built by Juan Galindez de Terreros in the 15th Century. It is a 15-metre high vertical building with square plan.

 

The thick walls, 1.20-metre width, were built in checker work. The ground floor was used as stables and storeroom and, sometimes, as a prison. The entrance was located under a pointed arch. The first floor was a residence and access was gained through an outer stone staircase. This floor is very high, almost half the tower¿s height, which originated lighting and ventilation problems. They opened big spaces to solve the problems. The second floor was the living room. The upper plan was a cabin, unusual in that period¿s towers. Moreover, it had some openings in order to defend the tower against assailants. The tower has undergone little restoration, the only one being a country house attached to it. The whole outer structure has endured all over centuries, except the roof.

 

Terreros Tower is part of the monumental compound of La Herrera, with Urrutia palace and the hermitage of San Antonio de La Mella.

The palace is a Baroque building dating back to the 17th century.

 

It has rectangular plan. Originally it was a tower house but restorations made all over the years gave, as a result, the present palace. It is located in the middle of Zalla, surrounded by a nice park. The building's most relevant feature is its coat of arms, belonging to Salcedo and Ayala families and located over the main entrance. A moustached man crowns the coat of arms, on whose sides we'll find two human-headed lions.

 

Nowadays the building is Zalla's Town Hall.

Zamudio tower is one of the best architectural examples of Bizkaia¿s lineages.

 

Located beside Zamudio¿s parish church, the coat¿s arms appear again in the temple because the Zamudio family, patrons of the church, wanted to give it a military touch. With almost square plan, the tower is a cubic volume, built in checker work and masonry. The space, turned into an exhibition hall, has been a farming house for many days. The library of the municipality is in the tower.

 

Type: Tower. Period: Sig15th century. Parking: Free car park in the surroundings of the tower.

The sanctuary of Dorleta is located up on a hill in Leintz-Gatzaga, Gipuzkoa. Apart from being the municipality's emblem, the virgin of Dorleta is the cyclists' patron saint. In the past the building operated as watchtower and defence for the inhabitants and the economy existing in the surroundings of the salty stream until 1331, when Alfonso VI granted the municipal charter and the parish church was replaced by the church of San Millán.

Besides, the sanctuary functioned as a hostel for pilgrims on the Way of Saint James. The appearance is of a 17th century building but due to the restoration works it has undergone over the years the sanctuary merges styles, such as relives from the Middle Ages. There is a sculpture of the Virgin holding his son and both look at each other. The Gothic image dates back to the 13th-16th centuries. 

Mass is held every Sunday at 12:30pm in the sanctuary of Dorleta from May to October (except the first weekend of July). Besides, on patron saint's festivities in early September a Major Mass is held along with special activities.

San Telmo Castle, located over a cliff in Higer Bay, is part of the defence system alongside Carlos V Castle and the walls of Hondarribia, which protected Asturiaga harbour from the attacks of the pirates. That is the reason why the building is also known as the Pirates' Castle. 

 

San Telmo Castle was built in 1598 by order of Juan Velázquez, Captain of Gipuzkoa. Engineer Felipe Cramer was responsible for selecting the location and designing the building that was later constructed in sandstone masonry. 

 

North and East sides overlook the sea and have enough room for five cannons. The West and South overlook buildings. An exterior wall built in masonry with a voussoired segmented arch operating as an access and guarded by a small sentry box. The wall extends from one of its sides and runs into a similar sentry box. The other two facades do not need defence walls since they face the cliff. 

 

It presents a blank and cube-shaped building and another smaller structure with a coat of arms of Felipe II above the access. The back facade overlooks the sea; it is built in masonry and bricks and has a platform for artillery in the terrace.

This building, regarded as a monument of the Basque Country, was opened on the 14th of September of 1901 with an outstanding party.

 

The Eibar people organised an exhibition of the material produced in the village -weapons, and so on- and, after the official party, a big meal was held and 'esku-dantza' dancing performed. It is a rectangular-based building of neoclassical style. It can be entered through a big arcade going from side to side. The main façade falls into five parts symmetrically distributed. The central part is prominent thanks to its columns and decoration. Its central balcony was the place where the republican flag was first hoisted on the 14th of April of 1931, a landmark fact that draws the attention of tourists and historians. Inside, there are portraits of some knights of the Order of Santiago.

 

The building was restored in 2002 but keeping untouched San Sebastián architect Ramón de Cortazar's original project.

The Unzueta family has been tightly linked to Eibar and Gipuzkoa all over history.

 

In the Middle Ages they took part in the side wars, fighting for the Oñaz side, that is the reason why the tower suffered many attacks. The present palace was built in the 17th century by orders of Mrs. Angela María de Unzueta, in the same location of the old tower, where not much remains can still be found. Two of its façades, those overlooking Azitain neighbourhood, were built in grey masonry stone.

 

The building consists of four windows on each of the floors with wrought iron bars or balconies. In the middle of the main façade the visitor will find the Unzueta family's coat of arms.

 

Nowadays it is home to La Salle Azitain school.

Located by Lazcano Palace, the Convent of the Benedictines -or the Monastery of Santa Teresa- was founded by Dame María de Lazcano in 1640. Since 1916, the Benedictine order, expelled from France, occupied the monastery.

 

Nowadays the building has a nice church dating back to the 17th century, built in masonry stone. With Latin cross plan, the temple has a nave and two aisles of different levels. What is more, it is worth mentioning the cloister, a small space with original stone floor in the courtyard.

 

The convent is also very popular due to its important historical archive where there are remarkable publications and books that date back to Franco's times. Besides, it also contains numerous magazines in Basque.

Tradition tells that in 1760 the Marquis of San Millán was strolling through the fields surrounding Zestoa when his dogs decided to swim in one of the nearby thermal wells.

The dogs, who were suffering from scabies, suddenly healed. It was then that they discovered the healing properties of the water and decided to promote this practice. Years later, in 1804, the Zestoa Spa was opened, thus beginning tourism in the area.

Today, as well as the primitive Casa de Baños (Bathing House), we can find the Gran Hotel, a building dating from 1893. After the serious flooding in 1983, the Zestoa Spa underwent major renovations of services and facilities to install the most modern hydrotherapy and spa equipment at the level of the most famous European spas.

Today it has 130 rooms, a large dining room, theatre room, hunting dining room, Arabic dining room and large social room. The entire complex is surrounded by beautiful gardens.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Due to its large capacity and versatility, the Zestoa spa is the ideal space for all kinds of family, social or business celebrations and meetings.

datosGenerales.descripcion: One of the most representative houses in Irun is the Arbelaiz Palace. Built in 17th century, a fire in 1936 that destroyed part of the old town also affected the building, but it was later rebuilt. Located near San Juan square, this nice building has a rectangular plan built in masonry and a hipped-roof. It consists of three floors and its main façade is made of ashlar masonry with two separate sections. On its sides two square towers soar and the building also has a Baroque door with two Dorian columns. What is more, the building has great historical relevance for it lodged important people ¿ Henry III of France, Catherine de' Medici, Charles IV, Catherine of Braganza, Philip V, Charles X of France, and so on. It was declared Historic Monument in 1964.

The church of San Pedro is one of the main buildings in Zumaia because, as it is located over a hill, enjoys a privileged position in the village.

 

The temple's interior comprises a single space only, with Gothic features. Notable are, for instance, the cross ribbed vaults and the polygonal apse covered by a 16th century star-shaped vault.

 

The building has the appearance of a fortress, thus, it is thought that the building may have acted as a defense for the village in the past.

The wall surrounding Orduña was the most important public defensive complex in Bizkaia. In past times it was almost two-kilometre long. Nowadays two thirds of the walls are still visible, part of them are behind the buildings. The stretch that is situated in the surroundings of the parish church of Santa María is the most visible one. A checker work wall reinforced with concrete and filled up with small stones forms the wall.

datosContacto.direccion: Junto a la parroquia de Santa María

datosGenerales.nombre: The church of the Sagrada Familia
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of the Sagrada Familia is known nowadays as the church of San Juan. It is a decorated Baroque temple dating back to the 17th Century. It has Latin cross plan, three naves and square apse. Inside there are eight altars, all of them in Baroque style. The outside part is in checker work except the main façade, in masonry stone. The façade is divided into two floors and the lower one, almost square, has a three-arch portico. Above it, at the choir's level, there is a big window and three inscriptions with emblems of the Society of Jesus. Two two-storey belfries finish the façade with a coat of arms between them.

This huge building was built following Carlos III's order, between 1787 and 1792. It was the place where goods were registered and that function determined the buildingýs structure. Apart from the offices, it had storerooms to store the goods and a residence for the administrator. The building has a big inner courtyard with arches and columns. Aduana is a Neo-classical building, with no decoration, with symmetry prevailing. It has three floors and a mezzanine. The main façade is divided in thirteen stretches and some semi-circular arches and windows divide the stretches. The three central stretches stand out and finish in a pediment with the coat of arms in the middle.

This hermitage sits in the beautiful Aldabe mountain landscape. This mountain is known by Irun natives as San Marcial mountain. The hermitage was built in order to commemorate the victory over the French in the battle of 30th June 1522.

 

The primitive temple was destroyed in a fire caused by a bolt of lighting in 1796; it was rebuilt in 1804, when the new image was installed. The tower was built in 1910. The building, however, suffered further damage during the outbreak of civil war in 1936. Outside the building, there is a stone-carved pinnacle with two headstones which commemorate the battles of San Marcial. Every year, on the feast of San Marcial (30th June), locals stage a procession to the hermitage and take part in traditional celebrations. 

 

There is an excellent viewpoint beside the temple, from which visitors can enjoy stunning views of the city, the bay of Txingudi, Hondarribia, the Bidasoa river, Jaizkibel, and much more.

The Urdanibia Palace is situated a few kilometres outside the town of Irun, beside a ford in the River Jaizubia. It is typical of the Ancien Régime period with a mill and an ironworks close by, and in the year 2000 all three constructions were designated a monumental site.

The palace is a three-storey rectangular building with a hip roof and a handsome facade.

The ground floor displays two windows with fillet mouldings around the edges and in the centre a door in the same style flanked by two pilasters. The panels between these elements are smooth and rise to meet a cornice.

The three windows on each of the middle and top floors also have fillet moulding around the edges, similar to that of the ground-floor windows, but in this case rest on moulded parapets positioned to give the impression of a single line.

On the middle floor the spaces between the openings are covered with decorative motifs. On the left-hand side, for example, there is an oval cartouche with the following inscription: "Sebas/tian de Ur/danivia re/difico es/ta ca/sa/ año de /1619" (Sebastian de Urdanivia rebuilt this house in the year 1619). There is also a cartouche on the right-hand side, this time displaying the family coat of arms. Between 1992 and 2003 the Urdanibia Palace housed the International Basque Pelota Federation. Nowadays, it is home to two libraries belonging to the Basque Film Archive, a temporary measure to resolve the shortage of space until this institution moves into the Tabakalera building.

The wealthy Gamboa family built Jauregia house beside the church. In the past the building saw several battles between the area's main lineages. The building underwent restorations several times but keeps still several medieval elements such as a wavy window and a pointed arch door.

The Lazcano palace dates back to the 17th century, as it was built between 1620 and 1640 and according to the architectural patterns of Castilian style it is surrounded by a wide garden. 

The building's façade comprises three sections: the entrance door is placed in the centre and crowned with a large coat of arms; in contrast, the lateral bodies look like towers. The distribution was a consequence of the latest restoration works carried out back in 1921. 

The layout of the interior is arranged around a central patio, where a well is situated. Nowadays the building remains closed.

The legend says that some kids who were bathing in the River Deba in winter discovered the thermal springs of Alzola.

Whether it is true or not, Doctor Francisco Platón sent a letter to Elgoibar Town Council in 1775 in order to announce how healthy the water dripping from some specific spot in Alzola was and ordering to find the spring.

Thus, in 1844 Pedro Manuel Aristrain registered this water and after demolishing Etxezuria farmhouse, he built a spa that opened its doors in 1846.

The spa was very successful in the 19th century and received many foreign visitors who came to heal up or rest.

Today, the building is not available as a spa, but hosts the offices of the company managing this special water.

This spectacular building is, nowadays, Zumaia's culture centre. It was originally built for the Marqués de Foronda as a summer residence. Designed by architect Juan José Gurrutxaga, the palace has a lordly aspect, which can be appreciated in different elements, such as its cut sandstorm masonry or the battlements. The Zumaia cultural house has a variety of premises and rooms with different characteristics for public use, a photographic laboratory and internet service. The municipal library and the historic archives, where all the documents from 1292 to 1960 are stored, are also located in the Foronda Palace.

The first records of the building that currently hosts the headquarters of the Departments of Culture and Basque and the Youth Information Centre date back to the 15th century.

 

According to the municipal charter, a quarrel between the owners of the dwelling and the Town Council set the building aside from the walled area. A record writing dating back to 1484 between the owner and the Town Council collects the change of location. It functioned as headquarters for the Town Council in emergency moments. In 1822, in the war between the 'absolutists' and 'the liberals', the house was fortified as a defence building for the right region of the town.

 

The Alzola Tower-House is a square-based, four-slope building. Most of it is made up of masonry, although ashlar is also present. The entrance is a round arch consisting of wide voussoirs. The family coat of arms is also outstanding and is located in one of the corners.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: The cultural centre arranges exhibitions, conferences, chess contests, and so on.

datosGenerales.nombre: The parish church of San Bartolomé
datosGenerales.descripcion: The parish church of Elgoibar, erected in the 17th century, was built by architects Longa, Larraza and Ibero, who were influenced by the Escorial's style, included within the Baroque architecture. However, other styles prevail in some of the church's elements: classicism in the high altarpiece, which hosts an image of the town's patron saint, San Bartolomé, and that of San Antón, Elgoibar's second patron saint. In view of its deterioration restoration works started back in 1994 following 4 years of repairs and cleaning. Works finished in 1997.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Religious services apart, several music concerts (choirs, music schools choirs...) are also scheduled during the year.

galeria.titulo: The parish church of San Bartolomé

datosGenerales.descripcion:
In the past the hermitage of San Lorenzo was the main church in Beizama and surroundings, for Agiñamendi neighbourhood was the first urban centre in these lands.

 

The hermitage's main attraction is the wooden structure supporting the choir. In drought times in the past, a procession would go down to the town from the hermitage carrying the image of San Lorenzo to pray for rain.

Martín de Larrea built Anunzibai Bridge, which constitutes a relevant heritage element because it is one of the most monument-like bridges in Bizkaia. Moreover, it is the main connection between San Miguel hermitage and the old ironworks. With rounded layout and only one eye, this Baroque and Classicist bridge is enriched with podiums finished in fantastic animals. Nearby the visitor will find the hermitage consecrated to San Miguel and the beautiful palace designed by Jesús Basterrechea in 1941 in Neo-medieval style and nowadays turned into a restaurant. Type: Bridge. Style: Baroque and classicist. Period: 18th century Parking: There is a parking zone in the surroundings, in Anunzibai palace.

datosGenerales.nombre: Hermitage of Virgen de la Soledad
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The hermitage of the Virgen de la Soledad is located on the road connecting Beizama with Tolosa.

 

It is a small sanctuary used by local people to pray for a good harvest. The hermitage was restored in 2001. Besides, the church has a small Way of the Cross built approximately in 1730.

 

In Good Friday afternoon there is a procession from the parish church of Beizama to the hermitage.

datosContacto.direccion: Carretera GI-3720, entre Beizama y Tolosa

galeria.titulo: Hermitage of Virgen de la Soledad

datosGenerales.descripcion: Aranguren tower, located in Orozko, is one of the most emblematic buildings in Bizkaia with its pointed arches and conopial windows. Linked to Olarte lineage, Aranguren tower was built in the 16th Century. It merges Gothic and Renaissance styles on a square plan building with checker work walls and masonry corners. One Century after its first construction, Aranguren tower was property of the Rotaetxe family, which gave the building its present appearance with high quality and appealing decorative elements. The tower is a private property so no visits are allowed to the interior Type: Tower. Style: Gothic and Reinassence. Period: 16th century Parking: Even if there is not a parking area, vehicles can be parked near the tower.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Pedro de Murueta
datosGenerales.descripcion: The beautiful church of San Pedro de Murueta, located in Orozko, has been recently restored, highlighting its beauty. It is a rectangular-plan building with two square stretches and three-length chamfered apse. The temple has beautiful brushstrokes in the apse and the nave. Likewise, we would like to mention the church's four altarpieces and two other excellencies: a Gothic carving of Saint Peter, dating back to the 14th Century and a Baroque canvas depicting Saint Peter's Denial, which dates back to the 17th Century. That is why the church of San Pedro de Murueta constitutes a gem of Renaissance architecture.

galeria.titulo: Church of San Pedro de Murueta

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of San Bartolomé de Olarte
datosGenerales.descripcion: The church of San Bartolomé de Olarte, in Orozko, is a simple temple with only one rectangular nave and square apse. In particular, the apse is covered by an excellent cross ribs vault with four tips and five keystones. The portico is another outstanding feature of this late Romanesque church, which dates back to the 17th Century, and the painted triptych depicting the Adoración de los Pastores, one of the main painting works in Bizkaia.

galeria.titulo: Church of San Bartolomé de Olarte

datosGenerales.descripcion:
No doubt the Old Part is the most visited place in San Sebastián.

It is located in the foothills of Mount Urgull, crammed into the harbour and the estuary of the River Urumea. The city was rebuilt following the 1813 fire and its streets; full of shops, restaurants and bars offering pintxos (miniature culinary masterpieces) and gastronomy societies present a lively atmosphere throughout the year.

The Old Part hosts two of the most relevant religious sanctuaries in the city: the basilica of Santa María del Coro and the church of San Vicente. Likewise, the San Telmo Museum, located in an old convent, and the Plaza de la Constitución Square, core of the city's cultural activities, are worth visiting too. Its colourful facades with numbers painted in each wall, reminds us that it was a bullring in past times.

These streets were walled till the Modern Age.

The San Sebastian Tourist Office organises a variety of guided tours.

Azkarate Marutegi house, also known also as Agirrebeña, was built in 1541 in Bergara following orders of Juan Martínez de Marutegi Azkarate, accountant of Castille's King. The building has interesting elements on its facades.

 

One of the corners, for instance, has a nice balcony built in the beginning of the 17th century and crowned with the family's coat of arms.

 

On the contrary, the facade overlooking Calle San Pedro Street, consists of 53 outstanding plaques in polychrome ceramics, made in Germany in the 16th century. Apparently, It is supposed that their function, in that period, was to function as a stove, although in the end they were used to decorate the facade.

 

Nowadays the building hosts the Batzoki (headquarters of the Basque Nationalist Party) in Bergara.

datosGenerales.nombre: Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de Udiarraga
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The church of Nuestra Señora de Udarriaga is the most emblematic artistic building in Ugao-Miraballes. It was in 1776 when the famous stoneworker Juan de Iturburu projected moving the medieval sanctuary to its present location. 

The building was built in checker work and had a two-stretch nave and chamfered apse. The sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de Udarriaga is one of the main examples of Basque Baroque architectural style. The most standing out element in the church is the 14th century image of Nuestra Señora de Udiarraga. 

In front of the sanctuary there is an information notice board with the major characteristics of the hermitage. Normally the sanctuary is closed. 

Type: Sanctuary. 

Style: Baroque. 

Period: 18th century. 

Opening hours:The interpretation centre of Ugao-Miraballes organizes guided visits, though visists are only from the outside. 

Contact: Historical Interpretation Centre (946 480 704). 

Car Park: Located in the urban centre, the sanctuary has several parking areas nearby.

galeria.titulo: Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de Udiarraga

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Arrese Palace dates back to the early 16th century. Its unique arch and little windows are typical features of medieval defensive buildings. However, a Renaissance balcony built at the end of 16th century in one of the corners confers it the appearance of palace.

 

The balcony is placed in a corner over the coat of arms of the family that lived there.

 

According to latest research, Pedro de Ibarra, who built the balcony, is the veritable artist who distorted some elements in order to adequate them to the perspective from the very floor. The building has Ionic pilasters on its sides, an architrave, a decoration-free frieze and a lintel cornice. Over it we will find the tympanum, in whose centre we will see a woman's bust.

 

The building hosts private dwellings nowadays so the visitor can admire it only from the outside.

The farmhouse El Bolo is a good example of local defensive architecture from the 15th and 16th centuries.

 

The building comprises two parts: the tower (15th century) and the palace (16th century) and combines different architectural features, the popular rural characteristics of the Basque Country and the formal elements typical of the Lower Middle Ages.

 

The construction mixes cut stone masonry in windows and corners, and wood and brickwork in the second storey of the palace. Its tower is a compact construction meant for defense, but at the same time includes several windows.

 

On the ground floor, the palace is open by an arcade and beams lean on five sandstone columns. Currently, it is a private residence.

datosGenerales.nombre: The parish church of San Pedro de Ariznoa
datosGenerales.descripcion: The present sanctuary dates back to the 16th and 17th centuries although it was built over a previous church. Renaissance style prevails even if the tower is Baroque, for it was built in the first half of the 18th century. Inside the building there are two gems. One of them is the canvas entitled La Adoración de los Pastores, located on the right aisle. This work depicts the Virgin showing new-born Jesus to the shepherds. It is a masterpiece painting because the painter put the light-centre on the baby and distributed all the other elements starting from that point. The sculpture entitled Santo Cristo de la Agonía is worth admiring too. Juan Pérez de Irazabal, the King's accountant, ordered this work to sculptor Juan de Mesa, one of the greatest masters of the 17th century Seville school. Years later he sent it to his hometown, Bergara. Many think that it is one of the best Baroque sculptures.

Gabiria Tower House was built in the basin of the River Deba, dominating over the area. Similar to other medieval houses, Gabiria consisted of all the necessary defence elements, but years later it was partially dismantled following orders by King Enrique IV and obtained the appearance of a palace.

 

Checker work prevails in the building, even if corners and openings were built in masonry. The monument, despite the fact that it was damaged in an 18th century fire, was declared cultural object by the Basque Government in 2002.

 

Following one year and a half works Gabiria Tower House reopened its doors in January of 2008 as the headquarters of Tavex Algodonera association.

datosGenerales.nombre: Church of Santa María La Real
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The first data on the church of Santa María la Real date back to the 13th Century but the present structure dates back to the 16th Century. Years later, in 1632, two lateral naves (those hosting the chapels) were added.

The tower is even newer, built at the end of the 17th Century by Juan de Aranzeta, from Elgeta. Finally, the altarpiece was designed by Ventura Rodríguez and has Neoclassical style.

However, the church's main feature is the portico, built in 1666. It is one of the best examples of Basque popular art, a wooden carving combining Renaissance and Baroque elements that captivates the visitor. It is in perfect condition after the restoration made in the 80s.

datosPatrimonioCultural.actividades: Music concerts all the year round

galeria.titulo: Church of Santa María La Real

datosGenerales.nombre: Hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Ezozia
datosGenerales.descripcion:
The exterior of the Nuestra Señora de Ezozia hermitage, built at the end of the 16th century, is very similar to that of the Santa María la Real parish church. This is due to the fact that both temples were built by the same master stonemasons: the Galarraga and Landerrain stonemasons, from Errezil.

 

The interior of the hermitage contains some real artistic gems, such as the Gothic receptacle for blessed water, a beautiful Gothic image of the Virgin Mary, and the geometric motifs in the wooden structure supporting the choir.

galeria.titulo: Hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Ezozia

datosGenerales.descripcion:
Ozaeta Tower House nowadays belongs to Koldo Lasa, who has established the Restaurant Lasa inside the building. However, the building's history goes back to the Middle Ages. It was built outside the village, near the road to Arrasate-Mondragón.

 

Years later, in 1565, it was rebuilt following King Enrique IV's orders to dismantle all defensive buildings. The house was the residence of one of the main families in the Oñaz side and there lived, for instance, one sister of Saint Ignatius Loiola. Besides, one of its last owners was another key figure in Basque culture and politics: Telésforo Monzón.

The palace's Renaissance façade is one of the best kept in Gipuzkoa. It displays all mannerist characteristics: sobriety, little decoration and symmetric distribution of classic elements.

The façade's central part shows a door that resembles a triumphal arch. The structure of the three floors is very similar.

On the ground floor, a semi-circular arch voussoir-decorated gives access to the house. There is an Ionic column on each side.

The main floor has a similar structure but instead of a semi-circular arch there is a lintel-opening and the columns support a decorated frieze. Finally, on the upper floor, the window is smaller.

Master builder Pedro de Ibarra built the palace that nowadays hosts private dwellings. Thus, visits are allowed but not in the interior.

The Agirre -or Agarre- is the only original raised granary built in the first half of the 16th century in Gipuzkoa. It belongs to the Town Council of Bergara, which restored it between 1983 and 1985.

 

Top ring beams and gaps were built in wood, without nails, and put together by means of a mortise and tenon joint system.

 

The raised granary is one metre over the floor and supported by four stone bases. Likewise, the staircase leading to the entrance in the façade is made of stone too.

 

The raised granary a large wood chest with different sections to store cereals, whereas on both sides there are departments to store nuts and dry fruit. As for the ground floor, there is a room that remains closed that worked as a garret for farming implements.

Irizar Palace, also known as Urrutia-Espilla, was built in the 17th century where an ancestral home was located. Ignacio de Urrutia, after years of service in the army, came back to Bergara and ordered the building of this palace to live in with his wife Ana de Espilla. It is a sober building with little decoration and surrounded by a gardened area. However, it should be mentioned a coat of arms located in one of the corners and the forging works in the balconies' balustrades. Curiously enough, in 1839, generals Maroto and Espartero signed the Bergara Agreement, which put an end to the I Carlist War. It was known as "Abrazo de Bergara" (Bergara Embrace). Nowadays visiting the interior is not allowed for it houses local offices.

La Casa Jauregi House was built at the beginning of the 16th century. Today it is divided into five floors, but the original structure was built with just three: the Ashlar ground floor, the main or first floor, and an attic.

 

Although it has undergone significant renovations, it remains as one of the most precious artistic gems of that era: a beautiful relief which extends across the first floor and which displays plant motifs, images of kings with crowns and sceptres, and scenes such as the hunting of a wild boar, a Troubadour and his lady, and fantastic animals locked in battle...

 

These reliefs were common in Germany at that time, and they correspond with the European late gothic style. The building currently houses private dwellings, and can therefore only be visited from outside.

This house was built in the early 16th century and is perfectly preserved thanks to its stone structure. The ground floor and corbels supporting the first floor, in Gothic style, were built in masonry.

 

The building is just behind the church of San Pedro de Ariznoa, in the centre of town. Koldo Eleizalde, writer and one of the founders of Euskaltzaindia (the Basque Royal Academy of Language), was born here in 1878. Barcelona's Pueblo Español Park shows a replica of this building.

The foundation of the church of Nuestra Señora de Orduña is linked with an old legend. The legend says that a shepherd found miraculously an image of the Virgin tangled up in a white mulberry tree on the foothills of Txarlazo Mountain. 

The building has Latin cross plan and the roof shows boarded up vaults. The façade is made in Baroque style and has a three-arch portico. Likewise, we would like to mention the Virgin's image, which is a spectacular Gothic statue dating back to the 14th Century, carved in lime wood and polychrome. 

The Neo-classical altarpieces are also worth noting: the lateral ones are made in wood and the central one in black jasper. Observations: It is open all day. 

Type: Sanctuary.

Style: Baroque. 

Car park:Parking is allowed on the adjacent streets.

datosGenerales.nombre: Historical and artistic site El Camino de Santiago (coast)
datosGenerales.descripcion:
El Camino de Santiago, through which pilgrims passed in the Medieval time trying to get to Compostela (Galicia, in the North-West), has two main routes: the coastal route and the interior one.

 

The coastal route in Gipuzkoa, begins in Irun and Hondarribia, to where it gets from France. After passing through Gipuzkoa and Bizkaia, in Bilbao, it diverts to continue through Cantabria across Muskiz, o through Burgos from Balmaseda.

 

In Gipuzkoa, the pilgrim can contemplate the beauty of monuments such as the Sanctuary of Guadalupe in Hondarribia, the ascent to Mt. Jaizkibel, or the hermitage of San Martín de Tours de Orio, patron of pilgrims. Then, the Camino cross the coastal regions of Pasaia, Donostia-San Sebastián, Zarautz, Getaria and Zumaia.

 

The Sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de Itziar and the Romanique Church of Deba are worth visiting. Already in Bizkaia, the route continues in the interior, getting in Markina-Xemein, where you can visit the hermitage of San Miguel de Arretxinaga and its triple altar. Then, the pilgrim will get to the only collegiate church in Bizkaia, the one of Zenarruza, in Ziortza-Bolibar.

 

After passing by the historical municipality of Gernika-Lumo, Morga, Larrabetzu, Lezama and Zamudio, you will arrive in Bilbao. The basilic of Virgen de Begoña dominates the capital and from there you have the stairs of Mallona which takes you to the Cathedral of Santiago.

 

In Bilbao the route is divided into several ones so you can continue across Portugalete, Sestao, Zierbena and Muskiz to Cantabria, or across Alonsotegi, Güeñes and Zalla to get to Burgos from Balmaseda, where destacan the Cruch of San Severino and the bridge of La Muza or Old Bridge stands out.

datosContacto.direccion: El recorrido comienza en Hondarribia y finaliza en Covarón

galeria.titulo: A typical signpost and yellow arrow on the Camino de Santiago

datosGenerales.descripcion:
The Bosque de Oma has a new location

Located in Kortezubi, within the Urdaibai Biosphere Reserve, in the same area of the Oma Valley. It is a more sustainable, more accessible and more complete Oma Forest, but maintaining the same morphological conditions and the age of the original pine trees.

Twelve hectares that maintain the same essence of Agustín Ibarrola's work. There are other trees but the language used and the connection between the work and the environment remains the same.

We will find the chance to build a personalised work by means of decisions that we will make in the forest, walking along one or another path, looking at different spots. Therefore, for each visitor there is a forest that exists in different ways. 

Free visit or guided visit

In both cases it is essential to book a ticket, which must be validated at the Santimamiñe-Oma service point one hour before the booked visit.

  • Online booking: https://www.bizkaia.eus/en/web/bosque-oma-basoa/home
  • Enquiries: oma@bizkaia.eus 94 465 16 57

Free visit:

  • Opening hours: from 9:30 to 15:00
  • Prices: Free of charge

Guided tours:

  • Maximum 25 people.
  • Timetable: Saturdays at 11:00 in Spanish and 12:30 in Basque and on special dates.
  • Price: General admission: 10 euros / Reduced: 5 euros / Free; Free: up to 12 years old, teachers, guides and accredited press, Nagusi txartela, accompanying persons (people with special needs).

How to get to the Oma Forest

It is not possible to get to the Forest by car. You have to walk from Santimamiñe to the Oma Forest (2.8km, approximately 50 minutes). 

The small neighbourhood of Oma, in Kortezubi, contains a singular spot known as Bosque Animado (the Animated Forest) close to the Santimamiñe Caves. The Bilbao sculptor and artist Agustín Ibarrola painted it in 1984.

This is an enchanted forest located in a magical area that stresses a new connection between nature and art. There, the artist left traces on trees and stones aiming to link the works of the ancestral Palaeolithic artists with the modern tendency known as land art, an artistic current that works directly over the natural landscape, being the landscape itself the artist's cloth.

Thus, Ibarrola confined himself to paint the surface of pine trees, being aware that the holder he was using was not as inert as the cloth. Most of the figures are scattered around different trees, which are situated in different depths. So, Ibarrola, when covering thousands of pine trees with colours and life, created an enormous cloth that each visitor can compose again playing with the perspective while walking.

galeria.titulo: Agustín Ibarrola's painted forest in Oma
Agustín Ibarrola's painted forest in Oma
